Posted: February 2
												Hearts of Iron III - the spiritual successor of E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial - is a simulation game which mostly revolves arround offering the player the most possibly scripted experience humanly possible.The Gameplay begins with constant random CTD's that can easily be solved after you just look up the problem find after ages of searching a link to the Paradox forum where a fixed .exe download is offered. So after you finaly registered yourself in the forum just to get told that you arent permitted to look up the forum for hearts of iron 3, just to be informed after another lenghty search that i have to register my game, just to wait roughly 2 days till the page synchronised with my steam library so i was finaly able to access the thread in the forum to download the fixed .exe for the game that will keep the random CTD's from happening. I have to say this kind of gameplay was totaly new for me, and i was really surprised that this here wasnt a ww2 strategy game but more an interactive online adventure! So yeah, after finishing the campaign that evolved arround getting used to how great the paradox forum, with the final goal of finding the hoi3_tfh fixed .exe, is - I started playing the additional minigame that was included in the hearts of iron 3 collection, i think it was called "Their Finest Hour".Their finest hour appears to evolve arround an interactive map full of scripted events with mostly broken triggers. Especially the politics simulation is mentionworthy, because states that loose wars badly and got every single town of theirs nuked wouldnt actually reject offers of the invader surrendering to them. I am sure that in reality when the USA would invade north korea and the USA would offer to surrender to the north koreans, the glorious DPRK would never accept such a foolish offer cause they would fight till final victory over capitalism is archieved.The overall combat in TFH has much depth, it is on a realism level that permits you to - like in reality - invade all of europe with cavalry in 1941 because the whole Luftwaffe and Royal Airforce is not Able to shoot down 70 units of tactical bombers that exterminate every single of their soldiers in europe. Meanwhile the victory conditions are on such an well working, level that after defeating all the allies, axis and comintern - causing all these pacts to not have a single member in the end anymore - the allies realisticaly win in 1948 and you loose, cause you arent democratic and the allies are democratic. they didnt had a single member but thats not relevant cause we all know that western ideology always wins.Overall would i recommend every player who looks for a realistic ww2 strategy game, to rather take the 10 bucks you would pay for this game and instead buy a peed in diaper on craigslist with it.

												Bought this game at Walmart years ago, easily put hours into, enjoyed every minute of it, then I lost the disc and forgot about it until I saw a steam sale for it. You wanna play as a small country and show those major powers who the boss is, go for it. Wanna play as Soviet Union bring communism to the world, do it. Wanna play as USA and skip ww2 and go right to ww3, go for it. The possiblilities are endless and there is countless hours of replayability. The vanilla game, no patches is buggy and crashes, so I have to recommend get For the Motherland and Semper Fi to get rid of the crashes and glitches. Overall, the game is great for the strategy fans out there. People who like action and gunfire and explosions should avoid this.

												HOI 3 is a great WW2 grand strategy game. I enjoyed playing as different nations and infuencing history to try and swing WW2 events in different directions. However the game is showing its age badly. If you don't use the Paradox support forum and try to fix all the issues the game will crash to desktop constantly. Even if you install the fixes that the support forum suggests I found that it is still no guarentee the game won't crash.I worked for 3 hours trying to solve the crashing issue and I still found that after a certain amount of time the game would still stop working and crash. Playing this game is not only trying to win WW2 but a war of attrition to keep the game running and make sure your save game works. Even the big fans of this game I've seen do let's plays of HOI3 have had issues with it despite obviously spending a long time patching it. If you play the game for extended periods and have a lot of units on the screen it begins to lag horrendusly. The UI will start to break and show no numbers. You have to re-start the game at that point. Which is a pretty big inconveniance.  For the technical reasons I can't give this game a positive review. The game is pretty much broken at this point because of its age. If you want to buy a WW2 grand strategy game just wait for Hearts of Iron 4.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												I ask you to read this before you downvote it. The reason I feel this game sucks is because it is not an imporvement on previous games, in fact, it takes a lot away that the other games had. Sure HoI III has pretty graphics and some overpriced Unit packs....but come on, is that really all you care about? Hearts of Iron III lacks most key events for WWII, as in barely any events are in the game. They try to justify this by saying its supposed to be a 'sandbox' even though that doesn't make any sense. First off; they are perfectly capable of writing up branching event paths that allow for alternative history like they did for the previous games in the series. This seems like an attempt to appeal to a new audiance that failed horribly.Among the events missing are some of the most important to include, like the aftermath of WWII! In addition there are missing mechancs like land trading and claiming that are absent from this game that are badly needed, there is also a lack of nations and alternative nations and ministers in the game too. And don't even get me started on the map. They also removed a lot of key bookmarks that are present in other games.The few features that are new or improved are poorly implimented or completely broken.I recommend you wait to see if HoI IV is any better or buy Darkest Hour.

												Hearts of Iron III is a pretty good grand strategy game. It is definitely improved since the first two games. It plays best with all three major DLC pack upgrades.In the game you spend time building up your army, researching technologies and limited trading for resources. Major countries can also persuade minor countries to join their faction (Axis, Allies, Comintern).When war breaks out things get messy. Many battles will be fought with your units. It is a lot of fun to see your hard  preparations at work.The game is fun but there are few tooltip popups or help files in the game explaining things. Such areas as how national Unity is raised are not fully explained and the numbers seem to be wrong. I am still not cetain of a few things in the game. I do know that Officer Leadership greatly influences Organisation and that Organisation of zero is when your troops retreat. Not certain what else Organisation does, or Morale. I have a few ideas but not certain. I do know that they are just as important as combat ratings. There are some wiki helps online.Anyway this is a fun game. I use the sprites for the units when zoomed in. For many decades I did not but the unit sprites look cool.Good to pick up this game when it is on sale.EDIT: Game is very clunky. Many crashes and lockups on loading because Paradox does not know how to program. Wait for Hearts of Iron IV = maybe, just maybe it will run better.

												Hearts of Iron is a excellent stradegy based game, it combines all the organization elements of running a military and the result is great. At first, the game is very overwhelming, and it may seem extremely confusing, but my suggestion is to watch some YouTube series' on the game first, this way you can understand what you need to do, and the crucial stradegies of the game. Another essiential in my opinion is the Black Ice mod. This mod makes the game heaps better, and adds tons of new elements to the game which make it feel even more immersive, Black Ice doesn't tally your game time on Steam though, so be wary of that, this is why I have such a low amount time played on the game. Overall, I really recommend this game for anyone who enjoys hardcore stradegy, this game does a great job of making the player feel like he is really running the military side of a country, the game is extremely addictive too. The lack of graphics may scare some, but most will adapt to it.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Hearts of Iron III is an excellent game. One of Paradox's best strategy games, in my opinion, it allows the player to control any nation in the lead-up to WW2, or during it if you prefer. These range from Nazi Germany, of course, to the Dominican Republic, which gives you an idea of the level of choice on offer. The game essentially drops you into the world as head-of-state of one of these many nations, and it's entirely up to you what to do from there: will you align with the Axis in Europe to gain your share of the economic gains in the upcoming war? Or will you side with Stalin's Russia and work to undermine Fascism and the Allies, in an attempt to dominate the world with Communism?However, the level of historical accuracy in HOI3 is astounding, despite the player's ability to make independent and alternate choices. For example, there is a system of "decisions" in the game which often provide some sort of benefit, one of which is the historical Anschluss of Austria for Germany. As well as this, there are literally thousands of officers, with their own traits and skill levels (which can be improved with combat), to assign to command your divisions or brigades. These are just two examples in an intricate web of historical detail. WW2 history buffs like myself will be elated at the opportunity to not only, for example, command Rommel's Afrika Korps, but lead it to complete victory in the Middle East! Again, this is just an example that popped into my head, the level of possibility is insane.Aside from the military aspect of the game, which is the focus, there are various other sectors of your nation that you can alter control. There is the politics tab, where you select your ministers and make policies, as well as administer the areas that have come under your occupation through war. There is the diplomacy tab, where, if you are a leader of a faction, such as the Axis, you can influence nations to join you in alliance, and make trade deals, sell equipment, declare war, ETC. Other tabs include research, production, intelligence. I won't go into detail on these, but all are as important as each other.Anyway, pros and cons:PROS- Insanely high level of historical detail (accurate divisional names, commanders, ministers in governments, literally tens of thousands of provinces)- Ability to relive or rewrite history, in your own unique way.- Greatly immersive, you get to the point where hours just slip away in what feels like minutes!- Huge scale wars, on land sea, and air, where you are the commander in chief.CONS- Not recommended if the player is looking for amazing graphics- the gameplay is what sells HOI3, not the visuals.- A tad buggy. The game crashes relatively frequently, especially if tinkering around in console commands.- Steep learning curve, but once you get the full hang of it, you'll realise it was well worth the time put into it.9/10 The cons do not affect my opinion of the game significantly in any way, and I hope that you too will be persuaded by this long-winded review to buy this awesome game too!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												If you like grand strategy wargaming, then this is the best one there is....provided you get at least the first two expansions, and preferably all three. People love to complain that its graphics are bland or unimpressive, but those people are looking for an RTS or shooter with lots of eye candy. This game is all about the grand strategy. Others may complain about the AI not being smart enough, but they overlook the fact that this is the best grand strategy AI ever written for a PC game and no PC based AI is ever going to be a match for a decently operated human mind. Now the specifics:Standalone game: somewhat buggy, some serious design limitations that impede some aspects of smooth game play. might wear out your mouse button with all the micromanagement required to play a whole game to the end. 3/5 starsGame with all expansions: very few bugs at all; added management tools and AI delegation options reduce the micro-management clickfest of the vanilla version to a level much easier to handle; custom game mode (CGM) from final expansion adds whole new worlds of replayability once you exhaust your options with the already incredible scope of possibilities. 5/5 stars without reservation - all time best of this class. Its only rivals for that distinction might be other recent titles from Paradox, e.g. Europa Universalis IV, though that would be partly a matter of personal taste, of course.If you are a casual gamer, stay away from this. But if you are a serious wargaming strategy-buff - this game is an absolute must have!

												While Hearts of Iron III isn't for everyone, people should not be grossed out or write the game off based on its screenshots. Despite most of the game being looking at a map, it offers in depth detail into being the government and military of a country with total countrol. Most players find peacetime the most boring time throughout the game, this can be worse if your playing a country like the United States which doesn't enter WW2 for quite sometime. However, people may find it boring during this peace / build phase but if its not thought out well you'll be quickly regretting and possbily restarting because you found that phase unimportant. If you are like me, and love to add flavor of events and hard decisions during peacetime especially and wartime I would highly recommend the Black ICE mod. This mod adds hundereds of historical events and decisions which have major to minimal impact on the game. These events can both be helpful and hurt you but I feel like it makes the games events harder as its not always a easy decision. For those reasons and the diversity of units and divisions that can be accomplished give you a more fun and tough time, as the AI also build more diverse and recieve events just for them to keep them up to par with you. If anyone ever has any questions or thoughts about getting or already has the game and just wants to discuss anything about it I encourage you to message me. As stated above I strongly recommend this game in its vanilla state or its various mods such as Black ICE, HPP and August Storm.

												Take control of a country, any country before/during WWII and see if you can alter history.Spoiler: You can. content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
 Hearts of Iron III is a Grand-Strategy game based in WW2 to the start of the cold war, to be more specific, 1936 - 1948, it was developed & Published by Paradox Interactive and personally is a spectacular Grand-Strategy.Hearts of Iron III (HOI3) is an educational, engaging and in-depth experience, it allows you to micro-manage every aspect of your military (Army, Aviation & Navy), politics, industry, espionage and more, however if you do not wish to be engulfed with all of these aspects, the AI can take over for you.HOI3 allows for countless do-overs and often answers the "What if?" questions comically or quite grimly, it has countless events that allow you to make choices about your nation, such as limiting parties or getting completly rid of a party and other events such as illegal acts.HOI3 also allows you to invade other countries though your military, yes, but also through your diplomacy and espionage, do you want to stop Nazi Germany from getting far at all? Then send it spies to ruin their party and make other parties more strong, however good luck with that. :)If you wish to have a friend to play with, you're able to do that, however be aware that the servers are not up anymore and you will be forced to host your own server through port-fowarding or using a program such as Hamachi, playing online is very interesting and is often more difficult due to the AI sometimes being very predictable.The game does suffer from bugs, game crashes and HUD bugs are very common and get worse the longer you play for one session. If the game does not even launch, it is often Steam or your system and a reinstall is very handy. Game crashes seem to get worse the longer you use a constant game copy, reinstalling this game every time crashes become common is a good idea and modding the game can also cause crashes, however I would reccomend the WW1 mod.I full-heartly reccomend this amazing game, with over 600 hours on Steam and much more off Steam, it helped me learn more in-depth about World War 2 and made me truly see the effects of the war. 9/10+Unique game with much replayability+ Extremly In-depth if you want it to be+ Able to attack a country through unique ways+ Great moding community with WW1 mods to game enhancing mods such as ICE-  Bugs, often forcing a reinstall after a unknown period of time- No official servers

												For the guy who likes to dig so deep into things so quickly he drowns in dirt; this is the game for you. But how should I describe this game? Imagine it as Civilization was taken thorugh several industrial grade filters and refined so far it lost it's flashy 3D graphics but became so rich in content it's hard to get the taste out of your mouth.Only having played about 10 hours so far I can whole heartedly say that this game is arguably the most complex I have yet come across. The inter-twined connections that just the technology section alone makes a newcomer to the Civilization-esk game genre very overwhelmed, very quickly. I know I was. But, once you read up on a game's mechanics ( Gasp! This is 2015, I don't want to actually read how to play a game somewhere outside the game! Hold my hand and show me the way!) things become much clearer and even if you haven't read the entire wiki like I have, you can kinda figure stuff out on your own.This game allows event he most fanatical of WW2 fanboys to squeal with joy at the historical events taking place in your games. It also allows WW2 fanboys to live out your most amazing/hilarious alternate history ideas in a world so deep, you'd mistake that you where the president of the US.Now for my Good, Bad and, Ungly section.  The Good  The complexity of this game has yet to be matched by any game I have played thus far. The menus are layed out in a nice fasion and automatically close whenver you open something else. This game will impress any history buff, regardless of specific period they like, as the detail to history is fenominal This is a great game to really slow down and think, you can make it as fast or as slow as you want  The Bad   The game lacks polished graphics and would benifit from them amazingly (Haven't bought any DLC, I'm talking about the stock game) Not being able to make some decisions because the game requires another condition to be met was frustrating (for example, not being able to change your economy because you wanted to stay neutral but you have to go to war in order to mobilize) Having to research a unit's basic requirements was wholy unnessicary (some units had half of their stats missing because one perticular technology wasn't reasearched) The Ugly  The UI is horribly outdated and just bad on the eyes, I feel like this is the original SimCity (as sated before, a bit of a graphical polish would amp this game's general apeal way up and would make more people at least try it, I recommended this game to a friend and he said "It looks so menu intensive and full of data; it just doesn't look like my game.") As stated by the people over at Extra Credits, this game does not hand-hold in any shape or form(there is a bit of a tutorial but it barely scratches the surface of whatt his game has to offer and it still leaves a newcomer alienated.) There's just so much information not given to you, it's hard to fully grasp what everything does untill it's too late(the detail windows that pop up when you hover over ceratain things need to have more actual, and more literal, descriptions of what exactly things do)And for all you Reddit junkies out there:TL;DR:This is an immensly complex game which will not only immerse you in detail and content, it will drown you in it. The UI and the game in general feeld oudated because of the lack of graphical polish and optimization. With this deep world comes a dificulty curve that's so steep, it's essentally a brick wall; but once you climb over it, the reward is almost priceless.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Its a complete pile of junk in terms of how it seems to run, constant glitches and crashes, more issues then you can count. and i love every second of it. Why?Because this is more then likely the most content rich, most enjoyable, most mindbowingly entertaining indepth stratagy games i have ever played. i will run through my issues with it first to get it out of the way.-lack of power behind airforce.Not only does it feel like it takes an eternity to build an airforce that wont be swept out of the air in seconds, but even if you completely out gun your opponent in terms of bombing power, or ground attack planes, they seem to do very little. air power is what won the war in the pacific, and what kept great britain alive, but in this, your airforce either get shot down in seconds from the ground, or they can sit over an enemy force for months and do jack all. it starts to feel like a complete after thought, why would i invest in bombers or fighters when i can simply build anti air in major cities, and mobile anti air for my army? why build bombers when they do minimul damage, even when your in full scale combat, a time you would think the enemy would be simplist to be hit. it feels hollow and empty, especially when certain nations dont have the tech they should, why am i starting without proper radio tech as britain? they created chain home, which i have built, but i dont have the tech to build more?-most add ons to provinces. this is a pretty big one. i had to go through wiki pages and asking uestions on help forums to figure out exactly what all the numbers ment in forts, naval fortresses, anti air guns ext. I know as a gamer that two naval forts are better then one, but in terms of game mechanics i have no way to guage it on my own. it will usually say +2 from fort. plus two to what? defence? hard attack? soft attack? naps? it has so many numbers and stats flying everywhere that it forgets to properly explain most of them, even in the tutorials.-navy. this sorta goes with aircraft feeling useless. during the second world war, the british empire quickly found out that the battleship was not longer the king of the ocean, after one of theres was sunk minutes after leaving port for the first time. but not here. because aircraft feels so useless, it come down to min maxing your ship composition, it takes a year or more to build one aircraft carrior (which yes i know it takes a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of time to build a ship) not to mention the upgrades to make it worth a damn, which take up valuble time that you could use for upping production. i have been able to win several games with only building destroyers and light cruisers, maxing out there weapons and armor, and building them on mass. because much like the air combat, it  feels poorly done.-casulties. very small complaint, battles feel.... incredibly small scale. if i send an army of say... 20,000 infantry and a few thousand artillary pieces against the same amount of infantry, once the battle is over, you will most likely have only last a handfull of men, a few hundread, maybe. i understand its ust numbers, but it makes historical events feel so small. landing on a heavily defended beach? eh.... 200 dead. firebombing capital as your military marches over it? 20 dead. as i said, its incredibly small scale, but in a game so indepth, i would expect them to pay attention to those small details. my men in hongkong had full supply, and were dug in as well as possible, had air support, and full moral this should have been a meat grinder for both sides, but my guys throw up there hands after 30 of them drop and leave there fortress of a city. and how many japanese did they take? 56-lastly there is a feeling of ultimatly missing somthing. perhaps it could have been fixed by letting me start a few years before it does now, or staying into the early days of the cold war. its just missing somthing. if i drop 14 atom bombs on germany they still wont give up, why? why does an atom bomb not destroy a city completely? why does it barely hurt a military force, only there moral? why can my naval forts not deal slight damage to ships that pass close by them? isnt that what those huge anti ship guns were for? why cant i trash everything as i retreat as russia? and most importantly, why do some of the lesser great powers feel so boring? why does canada play the same as chile? why does norway play the same as communist china? because there missing personal flair. and you might think its impossible to have that, but they have in crusader kings 2. now thats a completely different type of game yeah, but it still lets you have more control to have your own fun. why not let me have a bigger hand in designing my tanks, like choosing from a list of guns, rather then one flat out being better (which they werent) why not let me choose who i conscript for, like my airforce to speed up there recovery like the english did in the battle of britain. hell let me edit my own political party, sure it might not be historically accurate, but the great thing about these games is, its historically accurate up until the player enters the game.now enough of my complaining. the good.+Oh wow them tactics. i still dont get it half the time, numbers slip by you, hard attack vs soft attack, defence bonus, flanking bonus, composition bonus blah blah blah. i dont care.  its an amazing feeling when  you set up the perfect plan to hold back the germans before they can take paris, as you spend every ounce of strength you have to ust barely screech them to a halt. its a fantastic feeling to plan and execute raids on areas to try and liberate them, send a small force to bring greece back into the fight and so on. its great.+The tech. oh lordy its amazing.... just... look at it. so indepth, and i love it. 10/10 would get all agriculture again.+Freedom of choice. you wanna be mexico? how about poland? why not just play south africa? you can. any nation that was around at the time, play it. love it.long story short, there are alot of little things that might♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, bt at the end of the day, i have went through all that, and i still find myself turning it back on. because i love it. and i hope you will aswell.

Posted: November 1, 2015
												This game can be complex at first. It might take a while getting used to, but if you are a world war II buff, definitely get this. Especially so  if you felt like Hearts of Iron IV was not even a challenge at all. Seriously, 200 hours on HOI 3 and all I got to show for it are 2 full games playing as Germany Conquering the world and some random playing of several minors here and there that lasted until 1939 when♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan and I just quit. Have not even touched any of the Allied or the USSR as I am daunted by the task of playing them. Meanwhile, on HOI 4, everything is simplified and while it gave more flexibility in terms of diplomacy (Major Nations now have national focuses, allowing them to go ahistorical such as France joining the Comintern, as compared to HOI 3 where Factions were considerable more static. AI Italy, in a normal game of HOI 3 would almost certainly join the Axis all the time). While the role playing element was highly fun in HOI 4, the warring side of the game was lacking and did not show any semblence of the depth and micro that HOI 3 had. It simply did not satisfy the military nous within me. Fighting the war in HOI 4 is like colouring in a colouring book. (Assuming you arent doing something insane like world conquest with Tannu Tuva). In the end, you still got a complete picture but it just doesnt feel as satisfying as HOI 3. Fighting in HOI3 is like drawing on a canvas. It was tedious but the picture that you get at the end is damn well more satisfying. You felt like a real commander, microing each individual unit to help you gain victory. You feel more like an accomplished artist, not some 7 year old that was instructed to go shade some circles in a colouring book. You could just hand over your units to AI, much like HOI 4, but you won't cos the AI that controls your units here is rudimentary and should only really be used for garrisoning conquered lands and swatting rebels that pop up. The HOI 4 AI was meh, but it was functioning.Both games are good in my biased opinion (I always dreamt about directing military operations when I was young so this series was pretty much a dream come true for the armchair strategist in me) but both have pros and cons. HOI 3 is much harder to get into and very terrifying for a newbie but it feels more rewarding. HOI 4 is good in that games dont take as long as they do in HOI 3 and it is a much gentler entry into the world of grand strategy than HOI 3 is.TL;DR pick up HOI3 if you want a more complex game then HOI 4.Not that great of a review writer but then again, I am only doing this for a badge.

												I bought this game orginally without any previous experience of any other Paradox game, riding the wave of dissapointed and betrayed feelings after Rome 2:Total War's very rocky launch. I admired the fact that this apperaed to be nearest thing to actually commanding the conflict that one can ever hope to achieve, save for the people who actually fought in it. A very daunting, and perhaps even unfriendly game to beginners, it took me,  a realtively seasoned Strategy player of nearly all the Total War franchise, Company of Heroes and the even older Populous games, a very long time to figure out the games extraordinary complicity, and even today, I have only scratched the surface, after well over 200 hours of playtime. It is a flawed masterpiece however. The games AI, can be rather strange, commiting entire Heersgruppe's to deal with Norway, or in one instance, USA joining the Cominterm due to a pre-existing lend-lease treaty with Soviet Union. Also, those who have had their fill with singleplayer and dare venture forth to Multiplayer, will discover an ardous process of checking checksums, arranging private servers, and endless re-hosts,as Paradox did away with the Meta-server. However, Multiplayer can be very exciting and challenging, and even vetrans of singleplayer can be brought down by the novice in Multiplayer. Another great feature is mods, which deliver unparreled realism and depth, as well as hundreds of hours of playtime. To conclude, as I have said before, this is a flawed masterpiece, but certainly  a masterpiece of nontheless, doing something which, as far as I know, no other game franchise has done before, offering in depth realism of commanding any nation that existed between 1936-1948 in reagards to the Army(Airforce and Navy), Production, Diplomacy, Politics and Espionage. As well as that, it has thousands of real time generals, ministers, and commanders for each nation and party, even if you go a-historical, which is one of the games charms. A game that will never lose it's value or esteem.TL/DRBuy this game because Nazi nukes and Soviet cliches. Don't buy if your still stuck on the campaign for Call of Warfare 7: Battlefield Halo9/10

												If you're playing Hearts of Iron, then you have been playing variations of World War II. Such variations as Axis and Allies through Gary Grigsby's World at War. Hearts of Iron (HOI) is the most detailed WWII game i've ever played. Not only is the military detailed, the very foundation of your nation is at your control; determining Research and Int'l Trade. The game interface allows you to play any nation on the planet, no matter how uninvolved they may have been. Some fascinating games I've played include Romania, Yugoslavia, Norway, and Spain. The game has scenarios, or start in 1936 and plan the entire war. It is a real time game, pause is avail but has a (2 min) timer which permits others to release it. So, if you're REALLY ready to run the entire nationm starting in 1936, while deciding what to build (months are usually req'd per unit), and how 'buffed' they are with your research! Are your troops receiving enough supplies? Is your infrastructure in need of explansion? Are you doing the long, slow research for nukes? World War Two at its deepest player involvement!

Posted: April 1, 2015
												The game set high expectations but fail to deliver in too many areas. The bottom line is the game is very complex, unfortunately although I took the time to learn the various mechanisms, what I found behind the complexity screen was very disapointing and a bit holow for a strategy game which such high claims. It is not a completely empty shell, but the ratio of complexity vs substance is really bad IMO. HoI2 had a better playability overall.A major issue is also technical bug and glitches, just check the forums. it is a pity that after several expansions, and many patchs, that the game is still unstable.The game piles features upon features, but that didn't add up to make neither a interesting nor fun experience. From HoI 2 to HoI 3, each sub-systems increased in complexity, but this feels really gratuitous, as despite the complexity, the un-modded game is a poor political and historical simulation.. What the point in making such a complex game if the game so quickly move into fantasy land. in one game as the Germans, while I was dealing with Poland, Italy invaded France through the Alps in early 1939. In the end Italy reachedd Paris by the south in July 1939, at the same time I reached it from the north by the historical path. It so badly fails to reproduce the historical course of events, I won't give him any credits for portraying "alternative history" Worse for a WW2 game, the military operations are poorly implemented. Moving units is tedious, and combat feedback is very poor, you neither feel as a frontline commander, nor as a HQ staff officer planning operations. The idea of making a pseudo real time game (actually the game move in 1 hours increments), doesn't work so well with such a long and intense conflict. Micro managements is very high, but the tools and interface to give you orders are inferior to many 4X games.You can delegate a number of functions to the AI, however the AI is just bad even for simple thing. In fact it doesn't work well because if you pursue a specific strategy the AI assistance won't go in the same direction as you. For example setting trade on AI automation, the AI sold critical ressources I was in short supply instead of buying them. Another exmaple setting part of my units under AI control, I had the surprise that he AI abandoned the French Frontier in 1940 to move to the Eastern front leaving the border vacant.There is an important supply and command chain in the game: Division>Corps HQ>Army HQ>Army Group HQ>Theater HQ. However after a few days of battle your units can easily get messed aroundq the frontline as you react to enemy threats. Yet, tracking which units belong to which HQ is not easy as units and HQs are not color coded as in other games. Hence you spend hours unlinking and re-linking your units after every major operations. This is a real chore, and computer assistance is pathetic for such a mechanical task.The game attempt to do too many things at once but the end result is a failure.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Hearts of Iron 3 explores the thrilling history of World War 2, from the onset of the infamous war, to Nazi Germany's demise (or victory). Although the game does usually follow the real-world timeline, what-if scenarios can occur at any time, such as Japan invading Siberia, or a communist revolution in France, or even... the fabled Axis victory. Being able to strategize is a MUST, in HOI3, giving minescule armies the ability to conquer a colossal military force. If handling the military isn't really your thing, you can delve straight into politics. From firing Stalin (and probably sending him to perish in Eastern Siberia), to giving the German people, the right to vote, and hate the Nazi party. The other main part of Hearts of Iron 3, is diplomacy. A neat chart, allows players to see where their nation is on the political spectrum, and which alliance (Allies, Axis, Comintern) they're drifting towards. And so much more. I highly recommend the third installation of the Hearts of Iron series, and would pay more than double the price for this legendary game. Darkest Hour is better though.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												 where does one start with a game as conceptually hugamungus as this? Playing Hearts of Iron can be mentally taxing, intimidating, and utterly compelling all at the same time, and there’s no easy way to ‘sum it up’. But for want of a better topic, we’ll focus on what’s new, the most obvious being the graphics. Using an entirely new engine, Hearst of Iron III has been brought visually more in line with Paradox’s other flagship title, Europa Universalis III, making a shift from 2D to 3D. Counters, whilst still present at a certain level of magnification, have been replaced by generic 3D sprites to represent the different kinds of military units. The world map itself has been giving colour and life, with the different land types been visually represented. The only flaw to be had here is that the developers seem to have gotten rid of a lot of the urbanised areas, which is a shame because urban fighting was a major hallmark of this conflict.Not only are the graphics better, but the game ‘world’ has gotten bigger. Just as Empire: Total War shrunk the number of land provinces available to conquer, so have Paradox increased them, to the tune of around 14,000. That, coupled with the 100 + playable nations, means that this game is clearly the largest yet.The other ‘big’ changes are mainly to do with the AI and player interface. With a new streamlined military organisation system in the form of official ‘headquarter’ units, it’s possible to ‘assign’ the AI to various parts of your army. Whilst useless in combat, HQ units provide structure to sometimes unmanageably huge armies, and posse’s different levels, the top being the ‘Theatre’ command. Let’s say you’re playing as Germany, and World War II is about to start. Don’t fancy managing both the Easter and Western fronts? Simply tell the AI to control one of them. Assign it overall goals and objectives, and you can pretty much leave it be. Whilst the AI seems to get slightly dumber the lower down the command chain you go, it nevertheless proves to be a decently made system, and is definitely one of the games strong points.Indeed, this idea of AI control is a subtle theme running through the game, as you can assign pretty much everything to the AI, with minimal input. Reminiscent of Nintendo’s up-coming ‘Demo play’ feature, it begs to question why anyone would want to simply watch the game being played, but sectioning off certain areas to the AI’s commands can certainly make things easier on players who find the level of depth intimidating. There are a whole host of other minor improvements as well, such as the ability to customize divisions (the basic military unit of a game) mixing and matching the various brigades to form dynamic and diverse armies. However, most of these you will have to find out for yourself.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Hearts of Iron 3 is a real-time strategy game that places you in 1936 as a leader of a country just as World War 2 unfolds. You will be commanding troops, handling politics, and trying to keep your country alive. There is no real way to "win" the game as the real victory comes from achieving goals that you set up for yourself. Maybe you want the United States to become a member of the Axis or maybe you want to take a minor power and transform it into a super power; the choice is yours. Of course there is "realism" mode where everything plays out as it did in real life.I highly recommend getting the DLCs "For the Motherland" and "Their Finest Hour" just be warned that you MUST have them in that order, just getting "Their Finest Hour" will not allow you to play the game. The learning curve is also very steep, but after a couple of games you will figure everything out and will still learn new things later on.Hearts of iron 3 is a great RTS and it gets my seal of approval.A+

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I've tried all the major powers in Hearts of Iron: Germany, France, USSR, UK , US, and Japan. If you really want to develop an alternate history, you have to begin in 1936. The most difficult country to play as is Japan. The essential elements for success in this game are leadership and industrial capacity. Japan and France are both challenged in these areas. The easiest country to play is definitely the US. By begining in 1936, the US can concentrate on research and building industrial capacity BEFORE building units. To my mind, the worst mistake made by the Western powers was letting Republican Spain be conquered by the Fascists. If France, UK, and US had gauranteed Republican Spain's soverignty, they could never have been driven out of Europe in 1940. Worst case scenario, they could have retreated to Spain, and continued the war from there. Should the US joine the Allies early? No. Even if they have to support Spain alone, it is very important for the US to preserve it's freedom of action. In a game that I played as the US, Spain actually drifted to the Fascists BECAUSE the UK was bombing Spainish infrastructure. Defeat the Nationalists in Spain:yes. Destroy their country in the proxess:no.

content:
Posted: February 11
												Back when I was younger, when the original Playstation was still a thing, Paradox produced a LOT of rushed video games to cash in on the hype of what some refer to today as the "90s WW2 craze". These games shared many of the same qualities and problems: Shoestring budgets, tiny production teams, and camera issues up the wazoo. They also made convenient birthday gifts among the lads and even some girls; Mind you, this was back when gaming was still an almost invariably "guy" thing to do. Nevertheless, every kid I knew, regardless of gender, played them, as the characters were familiar, the gameplay was usually self-explanatory, and, if you got a PC version, you had the added satisfaction of spending so much time on Dad's work computer (and subsequently getting in his way) that when your next birthday came around, your folks caved in and bought you a computer of your own.A shining example of one of these games was Hearts of Iron 1, released toward the end of this era, in 2002. I remember sliding it into the disc tray one hot Saturday afternoon, and I remember being grounded for screaming frustrated obscenities at my monitor within earshot of my parents shortly after.The game was difficult. Apart from the camera issues I mentioned, there were also the instant deathtraps, the ridiculous distance between checkpoints, the strange projectile controls, and the worst micro I've ever had to do in any grand strategy game, but you know what? I couldn't put the game down. Despite its glaring faults, I pressed on, mainly to see just how hard it could get. Along the way, I discovered some fairer parts that I willingly replayed, along with a great soundtrack. More importantly, I became accustomed to challenge, and the satisfaction of finishing a campaign hammered into my mind that overcoming the constant obstacles was really what made games worth playing, as long as it gave me some type of pleasure to do so, but this isn't what I'm really here to talk about.This... this is Hearts of Iron 3... I don't know if this really qualifies as a game. If there is a way to fail at this, I have yet to experience it. If there is a way to not feel intensely bored as I slog through it, that, too, remains a mystery. If there is a "challenge", it must be hidden somewhere in the repetitive routines, if it exists at all.I mean, I get it. The game is targeted at little girls. Maybe I just feel sour at this younger generation for not suffering through their childhood with tough video games like everyone else did, but at the same time, I honestly feel that the target audience is getting a raw deal.The controls are terrible, and cannot be rebound. The graphics are bad. 2D objects are featured far too often, both in the foreground and in the background, in the most obtuse and noticeable way possible. Hitler's portrait picture, specifically that where he's lying on the beach, showcases this to an appalling extent. Speaking of Hitler, why are his eyes bugging out in two different directions? Did the designers never see his model in the Wolfenstein games? That is how you do it, and those were on the SNES, about three decades ago! Don't even get me started on how Churchill looks here...Of course, the biggest problem is just how boring this game is, and how many things exist purely for the sake of being a distraction. As far as I can tell, Blondie (Hitler's dog!) has no reason to exist, except maybe for screenshots to brag about on the internet, and to stretch the game out by mere minutes in giving the player something to customize beyond the army! Most of the campaigns are the same puzzles and micro over and over again, just with variations in theme (Poland, France, Kuwait etc..), all the while the player is receiving constant verbal reinforcement of "You did it!" and "Well done!"Perhaps the most striking thing I noticed is how the player is occasionally not just told to make war or kill civilians, but to *please* make war, or *please* kill civilians. The implications of this are scary. One, is that the game is either well-aware of the fact that it's an active chore to play through. The other, is that it is just coddling the player, the chilling shadow of soccer moms that I felt myself when I was a kid. They ruined trading card games, they ruined cartoons, and now, they've video games. This, ladies and gentlemen, is Obama's America.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2010
												As a WW2 History buff, this is the only game I have ever known to titilate and fulfill my hunger for the "What-ifs"... the "alternative" history of WW2. Imagine the Third Reich invading the American east coast. Imagine the Japanese Empire victorious in its attempt to dominate Asia and the Pacific. Imagine Soviet Russia at war with the Allies, or billion other scenarios in the mix. Imagine? Hell, with this game, you can play it out!Right the wrongs of the past, or do the opposite. Fight for Facsism or Unite the World under Communism. Liberate the world for democracy or swallow it whole under the Iron Cross, this game is at your command.Yet for all its grandoise, for all its freedom in choice, this game has it flaws. Bugs are annoying, there are some restrictions in gameplay, and severe patience is required for the slowness of its gameplay and pace. At its worse, it is a confusing, overwhelming mess of a game. At its best, it is the most awesome WW2 Sim ever.

Its really good that they introduced a new system to take care of all that and make the ai take care of the big fronts, becouse its really hard. They solved a problem they themselfs created. I liked it how it was in Hearts of Iron 1 and 2. But the tech tree is fun again. Not as fun as Hearts of Iron 1, but better than 2. Spionage is nice, and there is much to do, but I really dont see where it makes any different in the war. Diplomacy is as always lacking. Its so seldom I can do what I want or what feels realistic in the game. Trade in the other hand is better than before. Not perfect, but its easier now to build some more IC without lacking in resurses.Its a harder game, but little more fun, but it took some steps back i some parts. Its nice with brigade units, but its not when 150 german or sovjet division becomes 450-600 brigades on the map and even more, now when they need HQ to form up the divisions and amies. Its an awsome amount of units, and for me the change makes me less interested in directing the battle as in the earlyer games.Becouse of it. its with a small margin that i recommend this game.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												I've tried all the major powers in Hearts of Iron: Germany, France, USSR, UK , US, and Japan. If you really want to develop an alternate history, you have to begin in 1936. The most difficult country to play as is Japan. The essential elements for success in this game are leadership and industrial capacity. Japan and France are both challenged in these areas. The easiest country to play is definitely the US. By begining in 1936, the US can concentrate on research and building industrial capacity BEFORE building units. To my mind, the worst mistake made by the Western powers was letting Republican Spain be conquered by the Fascists. If France, UK, and US had gauranteed Republican Spain's soverignty, they could never have been driven out of Europe in 1940. Worst case scenario, they could have retreated to Spain, and continued the war from there. Should the US joine the Allies early? No. Even if they have to support Spain alone, it is very important for the US to preserve it's freedom of action. In a game that I played as the US, Spain actually drifted to the Fascists BECAUSE the UK was bombing Spainish infrastructure. Defeat the Nationalists in Spain:yes. Destroy their country in the proxess:no.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												I can safely say this is one of the best real time strategy games I have ever played. The accuracy of the history, units, commanders, map etc is unprecedented and I have never seen so much detail in a strategy game. Each country has it's own real military commanders and you're offered decisions that you can either make or ignore which caan change the course of history. You can influence other nations, declare war, trade and embargo them. Each new save is always a new experience, especially when playing as a different country each time, whether it be Germany, Soviet Union, Nationalist China, Australia, Siam, Sweden or whatever country you want. Each country has their own strategic and industrial advantages and disadvantages and creates a challenge every playthrough. I feel that although the vanilla game is brilliant on its own, it just isn't the same without the major DLC packs. However I believe that purchasing the DLC was a worthwhile investment. There really isn't anything negative I can say about this game, apart from the occasional crash and the lack of a multiplayer game browser, making it more difficult to get involved with others. I rarely give a game a 10/10, but the pros most certainly outweigh the cons so Hearts of Iron III gets a well deserved 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Recently bought this game after seeing some videoes of it on Youtube (Thanks DiplexHeatedHD). Hearts of Iron 3 is a game that takes place in the years right before and during WW2. You can play as any nation in the world, though I can recommend playing as some kind of major nation (I tried to take over Scandinavia as Norway, didn't work out too well). You can align yourself towards a faction (Axis, Allies or Comintern) and once you join that faction you no longer control your own diplomacy. So if you want to be a rogue state and follow your own rules, keep yourself away from joining any of the three factions. Be aware though, that a lot of the major nations guarantee the lesser nation's independence and you can end up in deep trouble if you get an entire faction on your tail. However as a rogue faction, you can potentially exploit the world war by grabbing territories from unaligned factions creating yourself an Empire, or you can join a faction and fight for victory in the world war.  I gotta say, the game is surprisingly good. Once you jump into a session it's very hard to quit, like today I played as Brazil and I ended up sitting for 7 hours straight because it felt so satisfying when accomplishing stuff such as liberating countries, annexing neighbors and researching new technologies. This is my first paradox game and after playing this for only 15 hours I already feel like I have to buy the expansions in the future and perhaps other paradox games such as Victoria 2. A great strategy game if you like to micro-manage an entire nation's economy, diplomacy, military, technology, politics etc. 9/10, would definitely recommend to all you history-lovers out there.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												As a veteran of this series I can say that this is the best out of all of them. For beginners this is an ideal entry to the series as you can have the AI control almost everything and you still get to influence what is happening and feel like a leader. For veterans like myself you can still micromanage as much as you want. The ability to build custom divisions adds another layer of depth. You get a special sense of satisfaction from moving your elite divisions to strategic points to break the enemy!Like most paradox games this one has its bugs. Most of them have been ironed out however this game often crashes on me. I found that weekly autosave and not using max speed during periods of intense warfare drasticly reduces that crash rate. Even after a crash starting from my last save is no big deal. This doesn't make me love this game any less, however the problem is still there.All of the expansion packs are great and really deepen the experience. There is also an abundance of mods available that are easy to install.

Product received for free
												You know, I played the game for a while, and I had read reviews with people saying "it keeps crashing, I can't play it," I thought I had an updated version of the game and they hadn't changed their reviews, I thought they were wrong. That was me without ANY of the dlc. A while back I bought all the dlc because it was on sale, and that's where I saw what they were talking about. I load up the game, everything looks the same, I go to load my save data and crash. It angered me a little because it takes a few minutes to actually load up the game. Anyways, after starting the game up and sitting through the loading screen, I go to load my save data again, and it crashed again. After that, I thought that maybe those reviewers were right, that the game can't go without crashing. After those two, I thought third time has to be the charm, and I try one last time. I start the game up, sit through the loading screen, but this time, I start a new game, as the game might not have been able to load the vanilla save for whatever reason, pick Germany, about 30 seconds later, it crashes again. It's at this point I stopped playing. If you're going to buy this game, sure go ahead, but don't buy the dlc, or you won't be able to play the game ever unless someone had to make a patch since the devs can't or won't.

Posted: August 30, 2013
												This game is awesome.You can play as any country before during and after World War IIIt runs from 1936 to 1948, but you can play longer than that with mods.You can control all aspects of the country, politics, diplomacy, espionage, military, everything.There are multiple start dates that go from early 1936, to mid 1944.Each start date has everything set up as it was in the world at that time.The earlier you start, the more you can change history.There are also multiple specfic scenarios to chose from, such as the Spanish civil war, the winter war, initial Japanese expansion into south east Asia, the Battle of the Buldge, etc.There 3 factions in the game; The Allies *Capitalist, democracy* Britain is the leader, and is the only member other than France from the beginning.The Comintern *Communist* The Soviets are the leader, and the only member from the start.The Axis *Fascist* The Nazis are the leader, and the only member from the start.Any country in the game can join any of the factions, as long as certain requirements are met. One time I got America into the Axis, and it was a serious "Where is your god now?" kind of moment.Anyways, it's an amazing game, and it has multiplayer, I would love to play it with some people.I highly recommend it, playing alone or with others.

												Very dissapointed actually.  I mean, it seems as though it would be a fantastic game to get into.  Really quite my style.  However, there seem to be so many issues with compatibility that crash issues abound.  Their forum is full of people with issues, and pages of potential fixes.  In the end, none of it worked for me.Additionally, they have packaged all the versions together, but Their Finest Hour should really be on it's own.  TFH is not compatible with the base game, Semper Fi, or For the Motherland.  So it uses a different launcher, and you can't select the other mods to play.  You have to go into your files folders and start the other launcher or launch the specific game version directly.In the end, the continued crashing has ended my play of Hoi3.  A real drag, cause I think it would have been great for me.STEAM, you should really address this one, and fix how the versions are packaged, at the least.

Posted: June 16, 2015
Best of the best for what it was meant for, but it's for a select few This game is the most sophisticated game I've ever seen. It takes it's strategy elements in the world map you are presented and lets you start off as certain countries in certain eras of pre-WWII and WWII itself. However...As I said, this game is sophisticated. It's REALLY complicated, and as long as I've played I've barely been able to rename a few units and move 1 or 2 divisions / fleets. There are so many complicated aspects I could see myself getting into as I get older, but it's just too boring as it is, which I understand. I really respect what it's done and I'm glad it was done the way it was; with no flashy action all over the place all the time. That's not what this game is for or about. But, I just can't recommend this game to a general audience. It's for a very select group of people. For me, I have to give a 6/10, but if I had to grade it's ability to do what it was intended to do, what it was supposed to do, 9-10/10. It's done what it was meant for with excellence, it's just myself not being able to get into this specific type of World Map domination strategy game.

Posted: May 10, 2014
												Fantastic Game !Iv'e spent more hours on this game then i care too think off, it's just so addictive.Unlike many strategy games where once you reach something the game is just a boring repeat this game keep's on giving. With all the many nations and different ways you can approach the thousands of situations, This game is challenging with its dynamic gameplay to the extent where even the most experienced strategist would meet his match.I must say though this game is not all true and great, First off there are the bugs and crashes.... Lots of them, Seriously. If you pick this game up save very very very reguarily. I once played as Ze German's for 9 hours, Conquered all of europe and just as i had the soviet union on the verge of capitulation my game crashed and none of it saved, Also don't expect any useful support from the developers, As far as they're concerned this game is dead. Some other useful info :1) Multiplayer does not work, You have to use third party online services to play multiplayer (LAN-Hosting). This can be tedious and is heavily prone to errors and not working.2) There are 3 main DLC for this game, Basically, The Vanilla is only 40% of the game, If you buy "For The Motherland", "Semper FI" and "Their Finest Hour" you will have the full game with lots less bugs and crashes, This is expensive though. Also you have to buy them in the order that i listed, You cannot buy a DLC pack without having the 1/2 packs before it,3) The community for this game is dying, if you have a problem that noone else has faced then dont expect support on it. If a forum about it didnt start when the game was new you probably wont find it now.4) Learning Curve, Hell, The learning curve is bloody mount everest ! I've had this game for ages and put countless hours into and i still have only scratched the surface of things you can do, At first glance the game seems complex as a mission to mars, And well... it is :). Do not expect to understand this game right away. Seriously look up how to play it and watch youtube videos, It will save you soo much pain. You may think "im a pro strategist i can do it", Seriously, you can't !. This game requires phenomenal amounts of micromanagment. (I like that though)I've probably put you off this game but i hope i didn't. It has its problems (And lots of them) but the hours, time and enjoyment you will place into this game are amazing.Hope i helped you make a descision of whether this game is good for you or not.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												As much as I REALLY want to recommend the game, I just can't, even after 700 hours in game. The main reason is that about half of those were spent trying to get the game to work, or replaying parts of the game repeatedly because critical crashes wiped out my data. And no, that did not happen in previous iterations of the game, I am still having crashes that wipe my saves as of September 2015 on a fully patched game on a top of the line rig. In short, if the HOI formula is what you are looking for in a grand strategy game, skip this and go for Darkest Hour (and especially for the Kaiserreich mod) or wait until HOI 4 as it looks like they ironed out all of the major flaws this game had.________________A Few Other Flaws_________________As if the game's crashing issues weren't enough, there are other key design flaws in the game that make it a less than ideal WW2 Grand Strategy game. The AI is a big problem in the game, as it makes for a very underwhelming experience. For instance, the Pacific Theater is completely worthless because Japan almost never invades more than a few islands in Indonesia and always focuses on mainland China. The Pacific War can easily be won in 6 months by beelining straight for the Home Islands. The British routinely stack thousands upon thousands of men in Newfoundland and leave the Isles undefended for a very easy Sealion. When it does fight, the AI favors a straight line in direct combat and will never make use of actual Blitzkrieg tactics such as encirclement. Resources are almost never a factor in the game. Aside from supplies, I have never run out of anything unless I did extremely foolish things. As Germany I never felt the crunch associated with the loss of Swedish Iron that prompted the Invasion of Norway (this isn't even modeled in the game), nor the crippling fuel loss by failing to secure the oilfields of Baku. The map is not just ridiculous looking (probably the worst projection ever made in any game) it is also difficult to use, especially if you opt for sprites instead of counters. Clicking on airbases is sometimes difficult as they are overshadowed by ground units in many provinces. The provinces are not optimized well either, and it is easy to attempt to click one province and have the game register it as the same province thus killing all of your units' progress. Diplomacy is not very functional. While it works in theory, they do not work well. As the Axis your conquests will give you extremely bizarre and nonsensical borders that are both hideous looking and nonfunctional. For instance, as Italy I staged an amphibious invasion in Split and pushed for Belgrade while Germany took the rest. After the surrender, my border was a giant green line going straight into what was Yugoslavia surrounded by German territory. This lead to a strange supply situation where, despite the obvious land connection, my supplies were instead routed via the Adriatic and then up to my garrison in Belgarde, causing undue use of transports that were vulnerable to sub attacks.These are just a few issues that come to mind, but are by no means all of them. Overall I do like the combat compared to other games in the series, but that can't carry the game. I wish Paradox the best as they work on number 4, I am confident they will make it the best one yet. For now though, get Darkest Hour instead of this.

												EDIT: I actually have played this game more like 300-400 hours, instead of just 30. It just didn't get counted through the fact, that I had to start this game manually via it's own .exe, as Steam forced it to crash.Somewhat complicated to get into, but totally worth it, once you understood everything.It's the only game that really deserves to be called "global strategy".You can play every nation during the begin of and throughout the Second World War. (And by that I really mean EVERY nation. It doesn't matter whether or not you want to play as Panama, Australia, USA, Germany, Argentina, France and so on and so forth. You can really play every nation.)As stated before, however, it doesn't give you a tutorial of what to do. You have to figure all of that out by yourself. There are a lot of Tutorials or some Let's Plays online though, where you can see how the game is played.From politics, diplomacy and trading over research and espionage to strategic planning, fighting and maybe even couping a country, you can do everything. (Or you can decide to let one thing be controlled by an AI, where you can decide which policy it should follow, so that you can focus on the other things more efficiently.)It's also quite open to modding and a lot of mods exist already. (You can also rather easily script your own events to make the game more historically accurate or to give it a complete alternative history twist.)I highly recommend it, as long as you are looking for a good strategy game that is really pushing you to the limits in terms of strategy. (Not in terms of mechanics though, as games like StarCraft2 are doing, for example. That simply wouldn't work out well in this game. It's not competetively oriented.)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												First off, by the date of writing this review (January 24th), I had not successfully played this game on a windows 10 machine, or on any machine. Within a few days of writing this review, I tried it again, and it worked. Thanks GandalfsBeard, as it did not when I tried it on a machine that did exceed the minimum requirements, but now does on the same machine I tried playing it on.The 21 hours GandalfsBeard is referring to were clocked by leaving the game's launch interface open on accident. I had spent about one of those hours trying to wait for the game to load and stared at a black screen. After the original post date of Janyary 24 2017 of this review, I did end up playing it to get the timer up to 25.5 hours, and it worked! It enthralled me so much, after such a long wait to finally play the game, that I was able to tolerate time elapse for a few years in about two games before I realized how terrible a game this is compared to HoI II in nearly every facet. From research, to UI interface and navigation, HoI III left a bad taste in my mouth. All the limitatiuons of HoI II were folded into HoI III, along with many new nuances that made this edition dul and feel more like a chore than a game. My expectations far exceeded the execution in this newer edition: the sprite animation is lacking, the information provided to the user is limited, troop navigation, diplomacy, espionage, research, all of these were built up from the previous edition in ways that deteriorated the appeal to HoI II. In HoI II, research was completed in one area once an area of technology was researched. I understand new methods build on old, but frankly making iterations of research based on historical year is too redundant and grossly misrepresents the strides in technological advancement these iterations achieve. All in all, HoI III was not fun for me, possibly due to previous exposures to previous editions of this game. In total, despite what the hours clocked say, I have really only played 4.5 hours of this game, and frankly, that is all I will every play. Previous review:Played HOI2 and LOVED it,playedHOI3 and... oh wait a minute, no I didn't.Thank you windows 10.** Note: THIS GAME NOW WORKS ON WINDOWS 10**

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												The reason why I don't recommend Hearts of Iron III is because of its various limitations which I do not think are overcome by its many features.The game is set between 1936-1948.  That is, this is a World War II game.  If you enjoy WW2 lore and strategy games, this is not a bad game - the strengths of the game include technological advancements; the use of era-specific units; actual historical events that influence the overall experience (to make it more realistic in terms of both chronology and "what are you going to do about that?"); and hardy diplomatic and espionage systems.  There are also levels of customization in terms of unit names, province names, and other minor details.Hearts of Iron III would be a totally awesome game if you could play it for much longer than just thirteen game years.  That is, the combat, economic, diplomatic, and province construction elements of the game are very, very cool.  But how cool can they be if you can't ever use them fully?  The biggest limitation, in my view (besides being limited to only thirteen game years), is that you MUST play as one of the great (or at least most significant) world powers of this era if you would like to do anything significant in this game.  If you simply want to develop, say, South Africa into an industrial or military or nuclear powerhouse - just to give the big boys a run - then you won't be able to do it (without significant modification to the game; you cannot accomplish this regularly).  The game is set up to historically accurate and plausible; so because a country like, say, South Africa never did anything so huge on a global scale, then you will not be able to make South Africa do anything globally significant in this game.  For those of us who like to play an underdog and build them up and alter world history, this game is not for us.  We are pigeonholed into the "realism" of the actual chronology and cannot do much to escape it.  So this limitation is probably ideal for WW2 enthusiasts, but it is certainly not ideal for us strategy gamers in general.For me, the two limitations listed above are what kill the game for me.  I am not a WW2 buff, though I do appreciate the historical accuracy in terms of units, events, and other things.  Nevertheless, as a strategy gamer, Hearts of Iron III makes it essentially impossible to play the ways that I want to.  So that is why I do not recommend it.  I could only recommend this game to people who are thorough enthusiasts of the period and only if you bought the full, complete game for $6 or less.  That is, if you just want to buy "another WW2 game," then this one can give you some fun.  If you want to use the strategy elements of the game, then consider a different title from Paradox (like Europe Universalis III or IV or Crusader Kings II).  Even then, many of the strategic elements of Hearts of Iron III are not available in other Paradox titles except for other limited titles such as Victoria II.  Again, Paradox limits strategy players with period-specific games that do not allow for breaking from the mold and doing anything too free-form and significant (except when leading to a quick demise if you go too radical).Just as a side note, the Hearts of Iron series (all three titles) is entirely limited to the World War II era.  Hearts of Iron II, however, had an interesting expansion pack that enabled a time frame into the 1950s where the USSR provided a fictional threat to the USA (similar to the storyline of Indiana Jones IV with the pseudo-history of fictional Cold War events or possibilities).  Hearts of Iron III, however, will stop you at 1948 - either you played as one of the major Axis Powers and took over Europe, or you played as one of the Allied Powers and prevented that.  Period.--------I wanted to provide some more technical or more specific reasons for why I would not recommend Hearts of Iron III to the general strategy gamer.1)  Some technologies have twelve tiers to them.  That is, you will research one technology twelve times in order to cap it at Level 12/12.  Some technologies will require something like at least Level 3 of one technology in order to research a different technology.  This is really cool, of course.  However, you will find that unless you are either the United States or Germany, you will not be able to cap nearly any of these.  (As the USA or Germany, you might be able to cap just a few, even though there are several you'd probably like to.)  This is all fine if you just want to play a period-specific, relatively historically accurate game.  If you love strategy games in general, then this is a major let-down.2)  If you want to modify Hearts of Iron III, then you probably should be (or will get to be) familiar with tweaking certain values in the text file of your savegame.  However, unlike Europa Universalis III or IV, Hearts of Iron III is not so simple to figure out.  And once you do, you will notice that there is not much you can significantly do to change your lot in the game world besides cheating to full capacity.  In all, it is ridiculous how limited this game is if you simply appreciate its strategic elements and also don't give a crap about historical accuracy.  But, of course, if you are a WW2 nut and just want historical accuracy above all else, then modifying the game should not be important to you, as this game definitely limits itself to that period faithfully!

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												One of the best WW2 strategies. About world war, not about moving tanks around.All common things, but much more realistic:It's hard to discover how to build tanks, if you never tried to build one.It's hard to build Armor, if you barely know anything about itIt's hard to develop effective combat doctrines, if your troops never fought before.New shiny tanks cant fight without ammunition and cant move without fuel, your cavalry at least could moveBiggest battleships without proper cover could be sunk by a couple of subs.Defeated division will retreat, instead of just disappear. It's almost impossible to kill entire division if they have a way to retreatYour troops are limited to your country manpower.A lot of troops can't fight efficiently if frontline is small.Diplomacy is tend to be more permanent than "allies today, backstab tomorrow"And a lot more... It's complicated, yes, but not actually overwhelming. And a couple of cons:Game is buggy. Weekly autosave is good, but crashes are annoying anyway.You have almost no controle about your own state policy. As Germany you could make USA nazi. But you can't become liberal yourself.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												First you conquer your neighbours and make them puppets if you can. Second you conquer your neighbours on islands and make them puppets if you can. Third you force any neighbours that are stronger than you or are tedious to invade to join your faction. Fourth conquer different continents with superior tech and make them puppets if you can. Fifth make your faction members attack every neutral they have borders with. Sixth sweep up any remaining people of the enemy faction, or those who are neutral. Seventh try to figure out how to invade Britain. Eighth crash your game. The End.As USA:First attack Canada and Mexico but only Canada wanted to be a puppet. Second I didn't have any neighbours on islands that are not in the Axis. Third I influenced Peru, Venezuela and Argentina to join the Axis and they conquered South America. Fourth I attacked Liberia and South Africa. Only South Africa wanted to be a puppet. Fifth I got Germany, Italy, Yugoslavia, Poland, Portugal, Japan, Republican AND Nationalist Spains, Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Luxembourg, and Denmark to invade Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg, (which was puppeted) Denmark, (which was puppeted) Sweden, Norway, Finland, Switzerland, Turkey, Persia, Afghanistan, and the Soviet Union. In the end Yugoslavia annexed most of the Soviet Union, making it rank 3rd in total victory points. Sixth I invaded Australia the neutral and New Zealand in the Allies, but only Australia wanted to be a puppet. Seventh I landed on the Scottish islands to try to stack up troops there. (even though there was amphibious penalty, it's also a bonus!) Eighth the game crashed. The End.It's easy to mod, just follow what the original text files say and your game won't break if you do it correctly. It's like modding crusader kings 2.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												A true masterpiece when combined with mods such as BICE. Perhaps the most comprehensive and in-depth grand strategy game available to-date.If you want to experience the closest possible simulation of armed conflict and all the associated things you need to manage (economy, politics, espionage, supply lines, diplomacy, forces composition etc) then this is the game for you.I would say that the game is quite complicated without any mods, but with mods it has a massive learning curve that requires hours of play time before most even understand what's going on, nevermind being able to actually win a game. A single game as a major power will require weeks/months of play time to conclude things, with the game being extremely punishing and implementing what I like to call 'major-management' - things you can't ingore such as the supply system which demand far more attention than comparable systems in other strategy games. Victory in this game does feel great though, owing to the amount of time and effort that needs to be put in. If you think you are a smart guy that knows how to implement war strategy and tactics, this is probably the best game to get gratification from, but you will probably belong to the vast majority (including almost all of the 'veteran' players at the beginning) that realise they don't know the first thing about real war manoeuvring. This is why I would argue so many players have less than 10 hours in the game (I'm looking at you, positive reviewers! - who obviously bought the game to look smart and cool!), not neccessarily because it's complicated, but because it requires real study and work to find success in. This is of course all assuming you are playing the Black Ice (BICE) mod, if not, the base game is still quite complicated and intricate but is a much easier learn.
