content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												A true masterpiece when combined with mods such as BICE. Perhaps the most comprehensive and in-depth grand strategy game available to-date.If you want to experience the closest possible simulation of armed conflict and all the associated things you need to manage (economy, politics, espionage, supply lines, diplomacy, forces composition etc) then this is the game for you.I would say that the game is quite complicated without any mods, but with mods it has a massive learning curve that requires hours of play time before most even understand what's going on, nevermind being able to actually win a game. A single game as a major power will require weeks/months of play time to conclude things, with the game being extremely punishing and implementing what I like to call 'major-management' - things you can't ingore such as the supply system which demand far more attention than comparable systems in other strategy games. Victory in this game does feel great though, owing to the amount of time and effort that needs to be put in. If you think you are a smart guy that knows how to implement war strategy and tactics, this is probably the best game to get gratification from, but you will probably belong to the vast majority (including almost all of the 'veteran' players at the beginning) that realise they don't know the first thing about real war manoeuvring. This is why I would argue so many players have less than 10 hours in the game (I'm looking at you, positive reviewers! - who obviously bought the game to look smart and cool!), not neccessarily because it's complicated, but because it requires real study and work to find success in. This is of course all assuming you are playing the Black Ice (BICE) mod, if not, the base game is still quite complicated and intricate but is a much easier learn.

Posted: September 13, 2013
												While Hearts of Iron III isn't for everyone, people should not be grossed out or write the game off based on its screenshots. Despite most of the game being looking at a map, it offers in depth detail into being the government and military of a country with total countrol. Most players find peacetime the most boring time throughout the game, this can be worse if your playing a country like the United States which doesn't enter WW2 for quite sometime. However, people may find it boring during this peace / build phase but if its not thought out well you'll be quickly regretting and possbily restarting because you found that phase unimportant. If you are like me, and love to add flavor of events and hard decisions during peacetime especially and wartime I would highly recommend the Black ICE mod. This mod adds hundereds of historical events and decisions which have major to minimal impact on the game. These events can both be helpful and hurt you but I feel like it makes the games events harder as its not always a easy decision. For those reasons and the diversity of units and divisions that can be accomplished give you a more fun and tough time, as the AI also build more diverse and recieve events just for them to keep them up to par with you. If anyone ever has any questions or thoughts about getting or already has the game and just wants to discuss anything about it I encourage you to message me. As stated above I strongly recommend this game in its vanilla state or its various mods such as Black ICE, HPP and August Storm.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												I'm on a reviewing spree tonight (I just got done with reviewing Long Live The...Queen), and I just had to do this one.Where to start?This is...the BEST game that Paradox has EVER made, and I hope they follow the same ideas that they laid out in this one for Hearts of Iron IV when it comes out this year.This is a wargame, pure and simple, so if you want to do societal stuff and other stuff, GTFO! This is for Jingo Reactionaries only (Vic2 reference).In this game, you play as a country in the years leading up to, during, and a little after World War II. How well that country does during the war is ENTIRELY UP TO YOU. You can let the AI screw everything up and build ten million escort carriers and stacks of infantry, or you can manage literally everything that would have any influence on the war, from the way your economy works (war economy vs. lassiez faire, consumer goods emphasis vs. heavy industry etc.) to what you actually produce, like tanks, planes and the like.You can even send spies to other countries to sabotage and assassinate, as well as lower the other countries' national unity to make them more likely to surrender once you start occupying their important territories.However, the best part of this game is definitely the Research and Development. Oh My God. This is Nerd Heaven.Ever wanted to see what the Germans could have done with King Tigers in 1941? Go ahead, try it.Ever wanted to design your own armies, down from the very guns that the regular infantrymen use to the tactics (obviously not completely, you just research the type of doctrines you want them to use) as well as the composition of your armies?You can have anything from a massive human wave of infantry to a highly efficient combined arms force of tanks, mechanized infantry, self-propelled rocket artillery, engineers and tank destroyers (this happens to be the type of division I always build at the last part of the game).Once you've built all you're going to build to get the war going, whether it's ships, planes or land units, it's time to get the war going. Sometimes it starts late or early, and you can choose to start it earlier rather than later (especially if you're Germany).After the boring peace years of accepting/declining trade deal after trade deal and staring at pop ups and sliders, the war part of the game is so amazing it feels like 10 different games are going on all at once. The land combat is flawless. Perfectly realistic and rewarding to the players that put time and effort into preparation and using real life tactics like encirclement, elastic defense, defense in depth and of the course, the most famous one...BLITZKRIEG!Seeing your small, but highly efficient army wipe out larger forces of dumbstacks of 3 infy and 3 tank is always a joy.Seeing your airforce that doesn't rely on bombing cities and instead clears the skies for your planes to do extra damage to their land troops is always a joy.Seeing the navy that you build yourself that has everything it could possibly need, from carriers to battleships and heavy cruisers wipe out massive fleets without even getting scratched is always a joy.The events in the game are here and there, but all of them are both flavorful and (mostly) realistic.You can also select who will run your government and your armies, and making sure that you're running a meritocracy is always fun.This game even has nukes.10/10P.S. Did I mention nukes?

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Hearts of Iron 3 teaches us that the failure of Barbarossa wasn't due to the resolve of the Russian army, the over-ambition of a dictator, or the logistical ♥♥♥♥-ups of the German army; rather, it was because the entire Eastern Front turned back to Poland to deal with a single ♥♥♥♥♥íng partisan that had sprung up.So besides a German AI that can barely make it through the opening stage of the invasion of Russia, the game has a lot of depth, much of which exists in appearance only: unit stats with no physical impact, political aspects that can't be influenced, and a supply system best described as "a monumental cluster♥♥♥♥" by leading journalists at♥♥♥♥♥♥Paper Shotgun.Somehow the game was released with unit stats like defence and attack (largely unimportant in a war game) having no function whatsoever, and though they fixed this issue for ground units after one of the expansions, they never did for air units -- their official response being that "clearly it wasnt particularly important"[forum.paradoxplaza.com] for unit defence to actually have any impact on combat.Can you still have fun with the game? Of course...but you'll often have to lower your expectations far enough to avoid crushing disappointment. Funnily enough, the DLC they're selling is probably more broken than the game itself: two of them were rendered broken by the first expansion pack, and won't even start up, while the rest of it is replete with graphical errors[i.imgur.com]. Meanwhile, the expansions exacerbate an already horrendous memory leak, which will cause the game to cannibalise your RAM until it reaches the 32bit limit and crashes -- usually every 1 or 2 hours.

												This is a very good WW2 strategy game, but requires a bit of tinkering you can get the game to look fairly decent - the vanilla game is quite dark and dreary I found so I lightened the fog of war a bit, added coloured airbases etc and now it looks great - look for Nats Mods on the HOI3 mods forum:https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/nats-mini-mods.643065/ Some of the DLC for this game conflicts with each other/doesnt work properly and it took me ages for me to get the game set up properly. Some of the German troops still dont have guns. I think it is some of the sprite packs that are at fault. You will need to go here to sort that:https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/hoi-3-tfh-spritepack-fixes.644947/For those with less time on their hands I have found Making History: The Great War to be very good alternative to this Paradox game but I have to admit that this game is far more detailed. The scenarios are fun where you can concentrate on the warfare, but the overall gameplay of a country in the main campaign is a bit overwhelming. I think Heart of Iron 4 will be much better and easier to manage when it comes out in a few months. I would wait for that is you are looking to buy a game like this.[Edit: Having said all that I've just played the Japanese scenario and had a lot of fun taking Singapore etc I think I am actually ready to dive into a full Japanese campaign whilst I wait for HOI4. Wish me luck!! It will be my first campaign ever tried properly - so far all my time has been spent on modding and playing the scenarios lol.]

In some games i.e. Warcraft 3: Frozen Throne, you can just build anything and chances are you'll figure it out what everything does without playing the tutorials. This game on the hand, wow. I finished the tutorials and still couldn't figure it out.. Feeling stupid, I searched up "how to play Hearts of Iron 3" on Youtube and found some useful guides.. Guess how long they were? Most of them over half an hour.. That's crazy!! ^^ I really want to learn how to play this game because it reminds me of RISK (my favourite board game). Graphics - 5/10: No commentGameplay - 5/10: So far, I have been able to learn every game, dfferent to the ones I have played or not, I can still pick them up. This game though, wow. content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
--Did what the Duke of Medina Sidonia could not do 427 years ago and conquered Great Britain as Nationalist Spain.--Conquered the Bolsheviks as Hungary.--Acquired Portuguese territories as South Africa.--Annexed half of Europe and kicked the British out of the Middle East as Romania.--Got drilled in my fine NatChi ♥♥♥ by Japan in 1938; drilled them right back four years and dozens of armoured car divisions later.11/10, would change the course of history again.I made this incredibly original review well over a year ago now. Yes I was trying to be funny but, looking back, I did injustice to a game I have come to love so much so that it ranks highly on my own list of best games of all time. Time to right a wrong.HoI3, as it is now well known, is a game of waging war at the operational level. The game is played out over a 2D global map, a classic trope of Paradox games (see Europa Universalis), and on it are represented all the world's major and minor countries at the beginning of the year 1936. You can select any one of these nations with the intention of controlling its diplomatic, economic and military development. The former two aspects are largely abstracted; you can select another nation to do business with but your options will usually be severely restricted unless you're playing multi-player or playing as a major power in single-player (Germany for instance). The latter aspect is much less so.Building up your military forces requires direct involvement on your part and you will need to make the critical choices to decide the makeup of your military forces long before war arrives, due to the nature of building units. The smallest land unit you can build is the brigade or regiment: a tiny fighting force of around 3,000 troops. The equivalent air and sea units are squadrons and flotillas. When you have concrete ideas on what you want to do, you then need to check that you've got the technology to do it. The technology tree in HoI3 is split into various areas of interest, including civilian technologies to assist in producing certain resources and doctrinal advancements concerned with improving the training and capabilities of your fighting forces. It follows a largely linear path, so to get to more advanced projects you will need to research the earlier versions. This process is based around game time, with inefficiency penalties for researching late-war techs earlier in the game. Trying to get to stage eight of Small Arms in 1938 for instance might present some issues.Leadership plays a critical role in tech research. Each nation begins with a certain number of leadership points, which can be thrown into slider adjustments depending on how many technologies you want to research at any one time. This needs to be balanced with three other aspacts on the scales, again depending on what your strategic choices are, which I will leave you to discover. People who play war-game board games will probably be quite familiar with HoI's primary resource pool: Industrial Capacity. This is literally what it says on the tin and decides basically everything in terms of strategic decisions. IC is used for such things as producing military units, delivering supplies to them and producing consumer goods to keep the common rabble happy at home. You will quickly learn that early game production is a balancing act, between keeping everything ship-shape and actually building the military forces that you want in quantity. You may often find that you don't have the necessary IC to build many different units at one time. The answer, of course, is to start a WAAARGGH!Before you start salivating, you should know that this is not simple. Neutrality governs the vast majority of nations at the beginning of the game, and you will have to start getting rid of this very early on if you expect to start annexing the neighbours before 1939, when the global conflagration begins. This process is a good deal easier if you're playing an Axis-aligned nation, since members of that faction get the option to begin wars with other nations quite a bit before neutrality hits zero. It really is possible to "conquer the Bolsheviks as Hungary", provided that beforehand you can absorb the resources of several of the other central and eastern European states that surround you.Which brings me back to combat. True to Paradoxian form, this aspect is also mostly abstracted: you drag a box over the military units you want to go on the attack and you right-click the enemy province(s) that you want them to hit. Control is still left up to you as to where you want those units to go however, and thus comes the pleasure of the operational nature of the game. Do you advance on a long front across Yugoslavia, taking each line of provinces slowly yet inexorably? Or do you punch through on three different sectors, in a miniature copy of Operation Barbarossa? Alternatively, do you concentrate your armies in one sector, smash through then expand outwards in a mushroom hoping you can cut off enemy forces heading for your undefended provinces? Such decisions rest solely with you.HoI3 definitely requires a measure of patience and actual cerebral work. If you are an FPS player, or stick only to tactical-level games such as Company of Heroes and Wargame, then you might prefer to steer clear. But, and this goes double for military history buffs and fans of other operational-level games, there are few other titles out there which could quite so effectively satisfy the need for a wargasm as much as this one can. Buy it. Play it. Enjoy it.

The game's tutorial isn't much help, especially because I hate reading. I hope a new video/visual/interactive tutorial will be in IV to help new players and casuals like myself. content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Paradox returns again with their newest WW2 Clunky Interface Simulators, bringing you the latest in paying money for minor graphical changes to the game.I have not gotten into the depths of this game quite yet (Though I have more than my fair share in Darkest Hour multiplayer matches), but from what I have seen it is not too bad. A graphical update from Hearts of Iron II, Oil needs to be converted to Fuel, diplomacy affects trade, and automation out the wazoo.The biggest change that this automation brings around is your theatres. You create a hierarchy of troops, and can give each part of the hierarchy a goal to accomplish, and the AI goes about doing it. The AI isn't too bad at this, but if you feel like you could do better, you can still manually select and control any divisions. My biggest problem with this system is how damn clunky it is to create the hierarchy. It could really use its own window to manage or something because individually selecting EACH AND EVERY DIVISION is ridiculous. However, once you have spent half your day organizing your armies, its pretty fun to manage. It makes it feel a lot more like you are a general of some form, assigning officers and giving them generic orders, and letting them do the micromanagement. But because its not required, you can still take care of any details you want and just let the AI deal with the rest.Overall, I would definitely reccomend this game to someone who is interested in hearts of iron in general, and especially if you liked Hearts of Iron 2. However, if you feel like you are completely burnt out on Hoi2, this may not be for you. The way you manage government, technology, and diplomacy has changed a bit for the better, but the base game is still very similar.Note: I have not played enough to say anything definitive about the AI.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Hearts of Iron III is like a once-beautiful Victorian mansion that's been abandoned for twenty years, and haunted. It's a beautiful, well put together game with a robust simulation, but it is aging poorly, and there's nothing Paradox can do about it, having somehow managed to lose the source code and with it, their ability to fix bugs. For instance, this fullscreen-only game has extreme difficulty making connections via multiplayer, crashes when you alt+tab, and frequently crashes in the middle of gameplay as well.This, combined with a somewhat outdated, clunky interface and a very poor tutorial, results in a game where you can't tell what's a bug, what's a feature, and what's user error. And it's never going to get better. It can't. Paradox can no longer fix or develop this game, because again, they managed to somehow lose the source code.I've never given a negative review for a Paradox game before. Do not let this dissuade you from buying games from them in the future. The bizarre and apparently unique blunder that led to HoI3's problems are very atypical for who are otherwise developers of VERY high-quality grand strategy games.Get Hearts of Iron II or IV instead of III.I really don't want to thumbs down this program, it would be amazing if it worked the way it's supposed to and had a better tutorial.

You also have an optimal build for your divisions that you can only learn about online...Nothing I hate worse than a game that demands you play optimally.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Strategy is my genre. I don't have any problem with Paradox. If you look at my hours played on Crusader Kings II, I've put more than a thousand hours onto the game. I've been playing grand strategy games for a long time, and Hearts of Iron III is just unplayable as far as I'm concerned.I picked this up during a Steam Sale, though I've since forgotten when I bought it exactly. I've attempted several playthroughs as different nations, and it's a long hard monotonous grind until Germany makes you take it up the pooper. Maybe I just suck at this particular game in general, but it's just not fun. To illustrate this, let me give a timeline of events for each of the factions that I've attempted to play as.1. Sweden - The biggest problem that I have with playing Sweden is that it's basically balancing on a knife's edge. You can't make Germany mad, because they'll invade, and you can't friends really very quickly at all. I spend a lot of time building up border defenses and units only to have the Third Reich plow over all of my carefully laid plans by about 1943... usually it's earlier than that. My earliest loss occurred in 1939. As best as I can tell there was no way to overcome Germany's technological/numerical edge, so after four or five plays through as Sweden, I thought to myself: "Let's try another nation and see if we can't change things." 2. Belgium - I was kind of going for a vaguely historical playthrough here. Maybe I could hold out a little bit longer than Belgium and France did in the real world... turns out... no. You can't. I assembled gobs and gobs of troops and fortifications, but the Jerrys were able to pull off the Schliefen Plan even earlier than in the real world. Yeah, I knew that I would probably get taken pretty early, but the fact that I didn't even put a dent in things on "Very Easy" difficulty was just frustrating and ridiculous.3. Brazil - If you're noticing a trend here, it's that I like to play factions that aren't particularly strong so that I can build them up to face bigger obstacles. While I didn't get invaded or anything like that, I got to a point where it was just a multi-decades long stale-mate. It finally ended when I attempted an invasion of Southern Spain only to have my massive army repelled by a dozen or so German infantry units.I'm so done with this Hearts of Iron III, it's just not a worthy playthrough. The graphics are just a map with strategic unit cards that look like Xs for infantry and Os for tank units, so you're not missing anything there. The only exception that I can think of on that score is that in the production screen they have some black-and-white photos of WW2 era ships and vehicles. If it weren't for the fact that I could literally do a google search for the same pictures, that might be passable.The game has great potential to just drag on forever while not allowing you to actually do anything to cause change in the gameworld. The intelligence system is a hindrance because if you want to attack anyone that's not already at a high threat level you have to sink all of your leadership into spies while sacrificing research and officers and diplomacy. All four of these things cause a trade-off that makes exactly zero sense.You start the game not knowing what tech that you need to research... then thirty hours into game play, and you still don't have a flipping clue as to what you need to research. The tooltips don't really explain what the different techs do very well, and there's not any way to divine exactly what you need.You can assign your units into AI groups. The problem here is that the AI that helps you coordinate troop movements is about as smart as a bag of sand - which is funny because the Enemy AI easily encircled my troops without a second thought. The end result is that if you want to keep track of a massive invasion of Fortress Europe, you have to monitor the movements of every unit card and every transport... you could spend several hours just lining up an attack only to have the Germans tear your carefully laid plans into very tiny pieces without much effort on their part. Your AI will force you to orchestrate an invasion by yourself, because it can't figure out how to boating.I spent the last 6 hours of my gameplay trying to get my Strategic Bombers to work to no avail. They just sat on the runway taking up space. I'd order them to bomb targets in mainland Europe and they'd just hang around... I kind of wish there was a mini-game where you can guillotine disobedient flight crews.I played through the tutorial of this game 2 times that I can remember. The second time I very carefully read every single word of the tutorial and it's complete BS. It's absolutely unhelpful. You get an idea of how to move your units manually, but there's no instruction on some of the more difficult things... it may be because the devs didn't even really understand it.There was a period about ten years ago where every First Person Shooter that you could pick up was set in WW2. Some were passable - most notable is Battlefield 1942 - but most of the rest were basically like video games of movies were during the 90s: just a ploy to make a quick buck off of parents that were looking to buy a game for a kid, and they thought "Hey, Jurassic Park, that was a cool movie. I bet my kid will love this game!" <cue sad trombone sound> There may be a decent WW2 grand strategy game out there, but this one is not it. I'm a little curious about Hearts of Iron 4 (just because I love Paradox), but if HoI3 is any indication... I just don't want to think about it. Save your money and avoid this one unless your cash is just burning a hole in your pocket.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I've been waiting for this game for more than a year, alas - all for $ 40.00 wasted Now I've been waiting for this game with great anticipation for more than a year. But all along, in the back of my head, the tiny voice of rationality kept telling me that there really is nothing else to add to the Hearts of Iron II series.Regardless, I pre-purchased the steam version a week before the release. I left work earlier and even skipped college just to get the first glimpse of this grand strategy - instead I got a stinking pile of $hit.Loading times, with my Quadcore 3Ghz was insanely long. Gameplay:Unplayable. Instead of the fast way to link or separate divisions by the easy use of a "SHIFT" button, we get a whole other display of the selected army on the upper left side of the screen. And for each division, we have a cute button all the way at the end that says "SELECT". Which means that we cant highlight divisions anymore, we have to "SELECT" each one of them. My favorite scenarion of all time was, of course, Gotterdamerung 44, playing as Germany. Now, with the HOI II series, it took me around 20 minutes at most to set up the right leadership, divison production, etc. With this game, it took me an hour, and not because I didn't know how to manage the game, but because of the tedious ways in which the game works. The leader icons are miniscule, you can barely see other icons indiciation either the ESP, or even ORGANISATION level. I mean seeing your organisation level is one of the most important thingsBugs:Quite often, you aren't able to select leaders for your armies, instead you might end up leading a leaderless army. Second, why in the world would we need a whole separate window for the Army leaders? what was wrong with the easy accessible leader-board on the left side of the screen? and what's with all down-grading generals? We can actually downgrade 5 star generals to 2 star generals? why is that an option? that makes promoting leaders just a silly joke. Promotion should involve long-term investment into the leader if you want him to lead either a 6 or 12 divison army. There might be more bugs in the game, I only played it for around 4 hoursProduction and Technology:The tech tree is $hit, plain and simple. Upgrading your infantry division with a couple dozen tiny upgrades, like better river crossing, better land fortification assaults, better mortar fire, etc over the YEARS is tedius and unmemorable. We all know that feeling when we get "infantry divison 1941 developed" or "Medium tank 1941" developed, instead of a max of 5 techs that we used to develop, we can now develop up to 20 mini techs. Do we really need "mountain equipment", "desert equipment", "jungle equipment" etc? or can we just get a nice 1941 division and add just ONE brigade to characterize the division's mission? And what's with these damn brigades comprising divisons? We all know that a panzer divison doesn't just consist of tanks, but of hundreds of trucks and thousands of personel and infantry. So why, would we need to customize our divisions by adding either extra artillery brigades, motorized brigades, etc? That just gives us more options which are confusing and time consuming.And I guess the ships are upgradable now. May I ask why? Dont we all remember playing as Japan and bracing for that "Carrier 1941" tech to deveop in order to start catching up with the US while we prepare for Pearl Harbor?The MAP:12000 provinces...really? why do we need thousands of provinces in South America? or Africa? or endless Siberia? Is anyone actually going to wage war there? wouldn't it be better if they just added more provinces in all the theaters of WW II? Since that what the game is about? Some people complained about the scrolling speed, I personally cannot complain because my PC can take this game easily. However, I thought the 3d water effects were pretty useless. And why don't we see armies sort of exchanging fire with one another like in HOI II?The good:Finally, they have introduced this following feature - casualty list. After each battle, you will get the amount of casualties on both sides. And I gotta admit, its pretty effective, it makes you want to immidiately research tech on reducing attrition, improving medical equipment etc. And so far, that feature is the ONLY one I enjoyed having while playing the game. If they could put that in HOI II, I would play it even more.There are definitley more things to say about this game. And I would be glad if more people tried enjoying this game. I tried desperate to enjoy it. I didn't want to spoil it for those who already bought it, but for those who are undecided, just think a little more before buying the game.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Just to add a bit of backstory, I was actually gifted this game by a friend who loves it.  He got it for me so that we could play multiplayer together.  Unfortunatly we never got it to work because he owned a piece of DLC that I didn't.  But that's not why I'm not recommending this game, that's just a warning for those who plan on getting it to play multiplayer.  The reason is because this game is VERY difficult to learn.  The previous Paradox games I've played were very fun and somewhat user-friendly, so I was surprised that I couldn't say the same about this one.  It does come with a tutorial, however it is VERY long, and for some reason they tried to encorporate a small story into it making it much longer than neccessary, and honestly very off-putting and more boring than your average tutorial.  I enjoy a good story, but it's surprisingly difficult to pay attention to when you're also trying to memorize what all the complex options under the technology menu. Speaking of menus, this game has menus.  Lots and lots of menus.  Granted, it is organized very nicely, but it's still a lot to take in.  It takes some getting used to, but if you're dedicated enough you can learn it.  In fact, I think that applies to the entire game in general.  It's quite difficult to learn and even harder to master. While I know a lot of "grand strategy game" fans will love it, I would NOT recommend this game to the average player.  However, if you've got a lot of time and you're looking for a complex strategy game, you might love it.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												This is for those that enjoy reading nitpicking reviews, and 'game theory' (in the context of video games, not economics).  It's NOT for people that are simply looking for a game that's fun.  If you value your free time, and value things like 'how long will it take me to learn the game?', then it's useful to read on.----------Right off the bat, the tutorial is horrendous.  It contains walls of text and a few spelling errors (that I only noticed because I was bored), portrayed in the context of a story (an interaction with a 'crazy man' that looks and acts like Adolf Hitler), that feels unecessary (he's only crazy because they keep mentioning that you, the player or character you're portraying, think he's crazy; so part of that is poor writing, if they need to remind you that he has that character trait...).  The only real reason it was done was to tell some jokes, but it clutters up the actual parts of the text that contain information on how to play the game in the first place.  However, the wording of the info is confusing, and I had to re-read the tutorials more than once to actually learn how to play the game.  This is pretty terrible, because a much clearer tutorial could probably be coded up in a work day, but they didn't do that.  Even though paradox is a massive company with many successful titles in this exact genre - so, it's not like they've never done this sort of game before, or had to write tutorials for these sort of games before.  It also sets the scenery poorly - like you have to infer that, for the sake of the tutorial, you're playing as germany.  Just because a grand strategy is basically a digital board game, doesn't mean that you don't have to scrap all attempts at presentation.  You don't lose out on the game for presenting it a little better.  I'm not asking for lens flares and all the faggy pizzaz that goes on in modern games, purely meant to catch the eye and be distracting as♥♥♥♥♥♥  I'm not asking for that.  I'm just asking for proper presentation that facillitates quick learning.  The tutorial doesn't even highlight the parts of the screen you're supposed to be reading very well, but that's a much more minor point.Here's an example of wording - 'You can build divisions in the production menu.  Divisions are made up of brigades.  You only get 4 (brigades?  divisions?), but our troops are so good that you only need 4 (brigades?  divisions?)'.  It's that sort of 'short hand' tone that can make everything else unclear.  If you don't know whether ol' Adolf is talking about divisions or brigades, then it's hard to figure out what the actual rules are.  In order to play a game, you need to know the rules - in order to get good at a game, you need to know how to play within the limits, so that you can tweak your style and discover an optimal level.  A game can have a steeper 'learning curve' effectively by obscuring the player's ability to percieve what is optimal - but there should be a point, I feel, at which the player can see everything that needs to be done to reach an optimal level (maybe after 100 hours of playing the game or so).  I think most players like organization - a game can only be chaotic if the means of playing it is simple.  It's a replayable game when the player can continue to have fun, riding the point of optimization (insert sexual metaphor here).  It's a confusing game, however, when the point of optimization is too obscure, or the goal posts keep shifting.  Unless the point of optimization is growing accustomed to the shifting goal posts, but it shouldn't take more than 100 hours to be able to see where that point lies.  It can take much longer than 100 hours to reach that level, but if the player can see how close they're getting there, they can still be hooked by the game.  Does this make sense?  It's my opinion that some devs have figured this out, and others haven't.------Second issue thus far:- The game crashes when I alt-tab out and try to go back into the game.  I don't understand what causes any game to do this.  Is it the display coding?  I've played several games that don't experience this problem (maybe because they're all capable of windowed mode), but there's plenty of others that can't handle alt-tabbing.  It's one of many software conundrums.  --------Other than that, I haven't had much problem, so I'll recommend the game because grandtards like northern lion love it, so y'know.  Who'm I to judge?  I might get into the game, but it'll probably take another 10 hours re-looking at the tutorials and ♥♥♥♥ing up in the regular game.

												Now this game, even though I'd recommend it, has very important issues people would really need to take into account before spending money on it. The game itself is very difficult, trying to control every aspect of your nation, including troop movements, and attempting to further your domination across whatever continent you are on is very very very difficult. It took me a while to learn all the tips and tricks, you can give your HQs objectives, and automate a lot of things, but learning that is difficult, and no to mention, not very fun for the 'Grand Strategy' fans out there. Overall the game is good, graphics are low key and not very hard on any PC. The biggest problem technically, is the buggy and glitchiness of the games start-up, you can't really buy the DLCs and enjoy all of them, or even some of them without having some start-up failure of some type. You can't really run into problems with the base game, which I enjoy, and the DLCs, might just be a me problem. All in all get the game, if you don't like it, its just 10 bucks, wait for Hearts of Iron IV to be released sometime in 2016 and that, I can promise you, will not be a disappointment.

												HOI 3 is more restrictive than HOI 2 in that it is more historically accurate. In HOI 2 it was easier to be ahistorical. In HOI 3, ATM at best I could bring the USA to war with the fall of Yugoslovia, could have China invade Russia but the germans took to long in France and by the time war broke on in russia they were already losing. Playing France I was able to hold out against the Axis, but don't think I can hold mainly because my AI Allies are being noobs. Invading Germany and getting their divsions wiped out or having 20+ divisions sitting way behind the front line, while the Axis breakthrough in France. The AI is still kind of weak or stupid. In Japan vs China, Japan should invade the coast, but in all the games I played it hasn't and for some reason more often then not they can't push beyond their frontline. Espionage and Diplomacy are still weak, though I did somehow get Australia to join the Axis. Political options are less than in HOI 2 so lack the ability to shape your nation. Research team is more personalized in HOI 2.  Easier to figure out your supply lines in HOI 2. Currently, having a severe supply problem when invading oversea, so my offensive eventually stalls out. So basically I think HOI2 is better than HOI 3, but this is still a fun game.

												I highly recommend this game, especially for those who enjoy studying history and enjoy alternate history scenarios. However, this game is all about micromanaging and is not for those who wish to jump in and play like in Call of Duty or other examples. The learning curve is very large but it worth leaning in order to gain hundreds of hours of enjoyment from this title. I would recommend starting off from a less in depth Grand Strategy game if you are not experienced, something like Crusader Kings 2 or Europa Universalis IV, and then moving on to this game. but once you know how it works inside and out, you are bound for some very fun times. Want to see what would happen if France had stopped the Germans, if Japan had invaded the west coast of the United States, if Russia had not been able to push back Germany, or even if the United States had never joined the Allies? Then you will love this game and enjoy it for years ahead.

												I play Hearts of Iron 2: Darkest Hour much more than this because of my older laptop. As far as I can tell, this version does not utilize dual core processors. That being the case, be sure that your system can comfortably meet the requirements -- especially if you will play campaigns with large a amount of units/provinces or utilize the high speed function.Compared to HoI2:DH, HoI3 features a more refined map aesthetic, more playable countries such as Siam, an in-depth Order of Battle system utilizing visual supply flow displays, and an Ally/Axis/Comintern graph for easily sizing up country alignments. When combined with The Finest Hour, HoI3's espionage system becomes an elastic warmaking tool thanks to the scouting and covert missions. It's a shame, however, that covert points are so slowly accumulated. If I could run it, I'd probably be playing this instead of HoI2: DH.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Hearts of Iron III is the best yet in the series. The political options are far more immersive, allowing realistic options to be made. You can play ANY country in the world at different periods of time before or during World War II. You have freedom to do anything at anytime, to anybody. Heck, I played as the U.S and conquered Mexico and South America. The U.S now makes the Soviet Union look small in my save game :D The customization options for each and every individual division you train, is just legendary. I can conscript a division and choose between 4 or 5 different brigade types to put in it. Perhaps you want this division to participate in the frontlines most major offensives. So you put an infantry brigade, maybe an armored brigade, a paratrooper brigade, a self-propelled artillery brigade, and maybe an engineer brigade or motorized infantry brigade. It doesn't matter, because there are tens of other different brigades. And you also research new technology to choose what model weapon they are equipped with. It's just absolutely amazing. You can also use aggressive action by one country to justify aggressive action of your own. Let's say, I'm the Soviet Union. Germany declares war on Poland. I can now justify mobilizing my entire army (this will bring all reserve units to full strength, and brings your normal divisions to full combat alert) because Poland is next to me. Let's say by chance, the U.S invades Cuba for no reason. I now declare an embargo on the U.S. All of a sudden, Canada may declare an embargo on me (not likely unless the U.S are their allies) It's a very realistic economical, industrial, military, political strategy game that anybody like myself can grow to love. P.S I also chose to be Brazil on a different save game, and I conquered and annexed all of South America, and I'm currently engaging in thermonuclear war with the U.S. Such fun :D at least 50 million people have died, and Germany and the Soviet Union are still going at it. (It's so fun!) I usually choose the time period of 1936, because it allows me to bring what country I lead up to full war preparations. Otherwise if I start during the war as belgium, I most likely am going to be turned upside down and gang banged to death by hundreds of German soldiers, and I won't have anything to stop them. However if I start two years earlier, I can annex the Netherlands and maybe Denmark, and then have so much fortifications and troops ready, that the German invasion won't go anywhere, even though it's highly unlikely it would be possible without cheats. But at any rate, I highly recommend this to anyone. The first hour or so of figuring everything out, might be depressing because it seems like alot to learn, but the wait is worth it. Buy this, and I'll give you a cookie. :) But then I'll declare war on your country in this game, and specifically nuke your hometown for the heck of it, cuz.... why not? :D

Posted: June 15, 2012
												924 hours. That is my total playtime of this game on steam, not counting my playtime via the gamersgate version which I also now own. I think that speaks for itself, but to give a brief summary of my thoughts, well, I can only say this: This is a game that will not appeal to many people. It takes a lot of practice, patience, and a love for long term planning and geopolitical strategy over combat and fast paced action. It also takes a love for history, the detail and the intrigues, and lastly, a large amount of, well, 'geekness'. For those of you who are history buffs, or who want to play a genuinely different type of strategy, pick this up, now. It is worth noting however that Hearts of Iron 2, and in particular Darkest Hour: A hearts of iron game, are in the political and detail senses generally superior games, but if you like any one of these games, you will like all of them for what they are, and that is a solid experience produced by an equally solid and player-focused developer.

Posted: July 20, 2013
												You're holding out against the Allies who are constantly amassing on your western front, and on your eastern front, where most of your forces are, your forces are pushing through the comintern forces who are constantly running out of supplies due to your strategic bombing runs, broken from the nightly bombings, and slaughtered through your superior tactics, combat experience, generals, and timing.This game is extremely complex, many decisions ranging from managing your country's economy, historical events such as the olympics and the spanish civil war, deciding where you should place more factories to fuel your war machine, to researching technology such as radios and even the nuclear bomb. The combat is very rewarding and fun, favoring those players who take their time to plan and pay close attention to details such as the weather, wind, climate, and landscape. YOU choose how you want to play. You can play as Germany and decide to play defensively on the western front, while you focus on the eastern front, crushing the russian forces, or play as Mexico and join the Axis, destroying weakening the U.S economy and splitting up their forces so Italy and Germany can more easily take over all of Europe. You can play as ANY country such as Japan, Swizterland, Turkey, Ethiopia, Mongolia, Communist China, Nationalist China, etc.TL;DR: Best strategy game ever.

Posted: August 6, 2012
												Hearts of Iron 3 is what I would discribe as a semi-real time strategy game. It is semi RTS because unlike games such as Men of War, R.U.S.E, Theater of War, etc, doesn't take place in a 3D battlefield where the player commands groups of artillery,troops, tanks, and so-on. In HoI 3 one takes command of the nation of their choise and can start anywhere between 1936 - 1945 and the game can go on until at least the 1948, and the player can control what go into their military, economy, diplomatic relations, tech, intelligance, and politics to an extent. As for air, land and sea battles the outcome of those are dependent on the exp of the units leader, the leaders traits, what type of units make up the whole unit, the exp each individual unit, total number of men in the unit as a whole, weather, supplies, time of day, terrain and so-on. Recommended Mods: DiDays I.C.E Mod. Current version: 3.3.4Black ICE FTM Mk VI. Current version: 6. Not recommneded for XP users.

												Honestly? HOI3 kind of kicked my♥♥♥♥♥ On first impression, all of that Paradox complexity is packed into the military aspects of the game, but a few hours of play will reveal that each other subsystem is full of things you need to know - so in short, it blows other Paradox series out of the water complexity wise and even leaves stuff like Dwarf Fortress in the dust. In short, HOI3 is ridiculously hardcore even by this company's standards. I haven't had much luck; a few games with middle/minor powers are about all I can claim, like the time I irritated the Japanese as Australia by screwing around in the Pacific archipelagos, or my semi-successful Axis Turkey campaign where I managed to conquer a decent swath of former Ottoman territory before Germany and Italy decided to invade India (and succeeded), before the Soviet Union decided to backstab them and wipe me off the map in the process with sheer numbers.I'd still recommend it to strategy fans, but you have to be willing to handle a good deal of micromanagement and get good at building overarching war strategies to do well. Master this, and you could probably get a good start on an actual military career.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Hearts of Iron 3 is a very good attempt at WW2 Grand Strategy. Generally, It's well put together, although at times, it can be hurt by the very things which make it so good. Sometimes, the fact that the game has so much depth and is, to be honest, slightly too big for it's own boots is a bit of an issue, although as I said before, it's still a very good game. The learning curve is occasionally brutal, and if your not careful then it can be quite hard to recover from things such as your dissent getting too high, which causes your entire economy to collapse. One main frustration that I have found is that the game does seem to struggle with transporting soldiers, in big numbers, to wherever your theaters of war are. For instance, I was playing as USA during the Pacific War. Because the game provides you with so many pop ups, and there's so much else going on aside from just what your looking at, it quite literally took me 10 minutes to get through all the popups, 90% of which were informing me that the Japanese had repeatedly "won" an air battle that I hadn't even known was taking place. However, once you've taken some time to get used to the game, figure out whatever faction and nation works for you, and work out the strategy that that country needs, then it can be, I feel, one of the most rewarding and generally excellent Grand Strategy games out there.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												I have lost count the amount of my life I have lost playing this game because its that good :-)Although I wouldn't give it 10/10 because there are some major flaws that give this 10/10 but I would say 8/10 would be a fairer assesment.  The game has become more complex but in some ways better for it, the creation of armies has now come more structured so you can spread your specialisation abit more. For instance an army could have a corp dedicated to attack fortifications via their generals or brigades. Its lost some of its military accuracy and some of the pictures do not represent the item you can build, for instance a Tiger tank shows a British heavy instead.However I will advise on what I think is wrong and why it looses 2 points.1: Alliance features.Wheather you decide to be the Allied powers or the Axis powers, they never seem to work together except use the ability to use friendly territory. A negative review below puts it correctlly, in this game they added the ability to create battleplans or use historical ones, but they do not work, the allies required do not follow though with the plan and do not offer units. An example of this would be Operation Torch and Husky. I played as the US yet the Brits did not help out in either operation. That being said if I was to counter argue this, one could say that because this game is unique that history never really plays out as it does historically, its possible that the Brits had all their transport ships sunk and are struggling to build more, also the fact that  they lost Africa doesn't help either. But that in its own way is a vilification that the game AI lacks the ability to think strategically and historically.2: The airforceI encountered this same problem in HoI2, were you could have top airforce training for your fighters and interceptors, and even good research, yet go up against anything, intercept bombers or even go fighter hunting, it seems to struggle to work correctly and always leaves me requiring to heal my fighters more often then anything else. Air attacks against ground forces is either hit or miss, either they do what there supposed to do or do nothing at all. I find the only really effective options is strategic bombing, which actually do damage to cities and cause some really nasty problems. But there is a negative there also, if you were to focus historically on WW2, Germany and Japan where on their knees near 1944 and 45 due to the effectiveness of stragegic bombing. New equipment could not be built quick enough and resources became low as factories became ineffective due to either lack of resources or their own destruction. Yet in HoI3 a country can overcome a bout of bombing very quickly and shake it off like a light bang on the head. This makes things a little boring and in the end you focus your efforts elsewhere.Inspite these issues I love this game and always revert back to it when I am bored of other games which is becoming often. There is so much to do in this game that offers new challenges, and more uncertain outcomes. As HoI4 in well into its development I will eventually get that, hopefully it will improve the areas I have gripped about, but we will see.

												I recommend this game immensely. Picture yourself at the helm of an alliance of like-minded nations wanting nothing but peace. A piece of this country & a piece of that country. 												Absolutely love this game and can easily lose a weekend to playing it. As a WWII history buff, I appreciate the amount of detail and work that has gone into this game! I particularly enjoy the randomness of starting off with one of the preset scenarios (1936, 1939, etc) as a Major actor in the war and watching it evolve differently than recorded history with just a few policy or diplomacy changes. For example, playing as the U.S. starting in 1936, I placed a large focus on my naval and ground power and gave mere lip service to production and development of my air assets. Though I was able to win the battle in the Pacific against Japan by 1944 forcing surrender without using Nukes, and able to neutralize Italy in marching from Sicily to Switzerland, I was mired in the battle for Fortress Europe as I learned quickly that not having adequate air power against the German Luftwaffe in France as well as the Low Countries was not a great strategy. My bombers were pummeled every time they lifted off, air support that I sent as escorts were being swatted out of the sky like flies and the Luftwaffe bombers made me pay for every square I took in battle. My only wish was that there were a proper way to co-ordinate with the AI/Allies to achieve objectives to more closely simulate real operations (Dragoon, Torch, Overlord, etc.) as the one that is currently in place is pretty ineffectual. Aside from that, I will continue playing this until the next iteration hits the market.Absolutely recommended!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Not that I don't like the control I get over an economy, industry, diplomacy, military of a WW2 nation, but it's not for me. For one, you don't really "manage" intelligence and politics, you just set a couple bars and hope it works out. For another, not everything is explained...at all. Watch Youtube videos to better understand some of the mechanics.Personally, if you want to just jump in and get experience, play America to practice controlling an economy and industry, then go Italy for some military experience. Diplomacy matters more to Italy than America, but mostly it's just historical events. DO NOT GO AS GERMANY IF YOU ARE CLUELESS! THE WAR STARTS, AND LARGELY FOR THE FIRST 2 YEARS, RUNS ON THEIR SCHEDULE! YOU WILL BE OVERWHELMED BY HOW MUCH STUFF HAPPENS AT ONCE!Also, managing armies isn't always straightforward. Note: if you're army has no supplies, it can move, but it cannot attack an enemy army (can still occupy territory I believe). You will take longer to move over rivers and in mountains without engineers (train lots). Finally, you cannot post any troops in terrritories with less than 2 infrastructure. Seriously, they are foot pounders...WHY DO THEY HAVE TO HAVE A ROAD SYSTEM!?Also also, while commanders give bonuses, it's not an easy system to understand. FYI: you set the stars, or "seniority" of commanders (just dictates how high a command they CAN take). Higher level: higher command since it'll take awhile to level up...unless they have an ability that's really handy to a particular army right now. Lower levels: tend to be front-line leaders, but not all abilities are useful (ie. supplies reduction is likely useful in Theatre (highest) command, since the most troops will be effected (even if the general is a lower skill level)Overall, while the sheer ability to command all major aspects of a WW2 nation is nice, not all commands are created equal, not all features and mechanics are explained in useful detail, and at times there is simply too much micro-management for someone like me to enjoy. Good effort, but improvement is definately possible and I'd argue nessecarry for this series.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Able to play any country from 1936-1948, hour by hour with adjustable speeds even in multiplayer, though only major powers and some regionals are worth playing.  Game really rewards thinking ahead, as in months and years (game time) ahead.  Multiplayer is recommended, AI is easy to beat, though it'll still put up a good enough fight for you to enjoy singleplayer.  All 3 expansions are REQUIRED, they add and fix so many things, the game is not worth playing without them.  (Expansions are Semper Fi, For the Motherland, and Their Finest Hour, do NOT bother with any other DLC, except the music packs if you want those.)This is a war game, don't expect any diplomatic, cultural, scientific, or economic victories.  The only thing that matters at the end of the day is whose troops are in the capitols of their enemies.Air operations are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to manage.Naval operations are simple but get the job done.Ground operations are where this game ♥♥♥♥ing shines.The Order Of Battle can be a little annoying to set up.Diplomacy is very simple, as is Intelligence and Internal Politics, generally allowing you to set and forget.Research and Production are where you have the most freedom to do as you wish with your country.Your basic air units are Air Wings, which you group up into 2s, 3s, or 4s, and have them perform whatever role they're designed to, Interceptors will generally be flying air superiority or interception, Close Air Support will generally be bombing enemy ground units, etc.Ships larger than a destroyer are produced individually and grouped together to form task forces which perform whatever mission they can from the ships assigned.  Carriers can be sent to bomb enemy ports or fleets, Battleships are generally used to form the fighting line of your fleets, engaging other battleships, bombarding, etc.  Destroyers are represented by Destroyer Flotillas, each Destroyer Flotilla in game is supposed to represent about 3 Destroyers, they are used to screen your larger ships.Your basic ground unit is the Division, which is made up of individual brigades of your choice, anything from your standard Infantry brigade to Artillery brigades or Heavy Armour brigades, there are a lot of choices.  The brigades all add certain bonuses and maluses to the division as a whole and this determines how effective it is in combat in the various terrains against other divisions.  There is a lot that goes into what makes a good division, terrain, cost (in industrial capacity, supplies, and manpower), tech level, your enemies, and more.  Countries like the USA can afford to go heavy on support units and armour because of their abundance of everything, while other countries like Japan may find itself not being able to make a lot of support or armour because of their shortages of everything, nor would they normally want to make a lot of armour because of all the low infrastructure mountains and jungles they'll usually find themselves fighting in (not the best tank country).  You'll find yourself fielding a number of different types of divisions for all the situations you'll be dealing with.Most games against the AI will play out historically until 1941 or 42, it will not deviate from the script, though sometimes it can make a mistake against the other AI and get bogged down taking longer to do what it historically did.  After 1942 it's all up in the air depending on how you and the various AI are doing.  Against other players, this game offers a lot of different routes to alternate history scenarios.Definitely worth picking up on a sale if you're into WW2 games or grand strategy games in general.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Hearts of Iron III, simply put, is a spectacularly good grand strategy game. Though players will initially find it daunting due to the number of mechanics in play at once (your first war will most certainly be confusing), if you take the time to learn the gameplay mechanics, either by playing or searching online, you'll eventually get to grips with it - it took me no longer than about 5-10 hours to understand most of the important game mechanics, though I still occasionally find myself learning something new. That said, I have some friends who haven't been able to understand the gameplay (which turned multiplayer into a bit of a hand-holding scenario), so it won't be for everyone. Once you've gotten into the real meat-and-bones of the gameplay, Hearts of Iron III has a lot to offer. The number of nations available for the player to choose is simply amazing - you can choose anybody from the mighty USSR down to Luxembourg or Costa Rica, and this really allows the gameplay to evolve with every new game. This, along with the ability to completely alter the history of the world in the 1930s and 1940s, is what really makes the game shine. Freedom is granted to the player to make an aggressive superpower out of Sweden, or to launch an invasion of the U.S.A as Nazi Germany. The scope of the game is immense, and the detail on the campaign map is brilliant. The combat, once you've got the hang of it, is fun, and the wars you will find yourself in can take anywhere from a minute to several days of gameplay to bring to a conclusion. The AI is occasionally partial to moments of pants-on-head stupidity though, which sometimes let the game down a bit. Multiplayer, although I haven't played much of it admittedly, was good for the most part. Gameplay is, of course, identical to the campaign, but the new elements that a human player, as opposed to an AI, bring to the game make it downright entertaining. Player politics in the multiplayer can be treacherous (indeed, a good comparison for the player politics in the multiplayer would be to Risk, or Civ 5), but it also allows for some interesting co-operation between historical rivals (the USSR and Nazi Germany in one of my games, for instance - though admittedly this came with a great deal of backstabbing on my behalf!). Overall, it's a wonderfully well presented Grand strategy game. The world is your sandbox, and history is ripe for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation. If you have the time to spare to get to grasps with the gameplay, I'd fully recommend it. It is, however, a real time sink, so if you don't have that much free time, it may not be for you.

												Now this game, even though I'd recommend it, has very important issues people would really need to take into account before spending money on it. It took me a while to learn all the tips and tricks, you can give your HQs objectives, and automate a lot of things, but learning that is difficult, and no to mention, not very fun for the 'Grand Strategy' fans out there. Overall the game is good, graphics are low key and not very hard on any PC. The biggest problem technically, is the buggy and glitchiness of the games start-up, you can't really buy the DLCs and enjoy all of them, or even some of them without having some start-up failure of some type. You can't really run into problems with the base game, which I enjoy, and the DLCs, might just be a me problem. All in all get the game, if you don't like it, its just 10 bucks, wait for Hearts of Iron IV to be released sometime in 2016 and that, I can promise you, will not be a disappointment.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												This is for those that enjoy reading nitpicking reviews, and 'game theory' (in the context of video games, not economics).  It's NOT for people that are simply looking for a game that's fun.  If you value your free time, and value things like 'how long will it take me to learn the game?', then it's useful to read on.----------Right off the bat, the tutorial is horrendous.  It contains walls of text and a few spelling errors (that I only noticed because I was bored), portrayed in the context of a story (an interaction with a 'crazy man' that looks and acts like Adolf Hitler), that feels unecessary (he's only crazy because they keep mentioning that you, the player or character you're portraying, think he's crazy; so part of that is poor writing, if they need to remind you that he has that character trait...).  The only real reason it was done was to tell some jokes, but it clutters up the actual parts of the text that contain information on how to play the game in the first place.  However, the wording of the info is confusing, and I had to re-read the tutorials more than once to actually learn how to play the game.  This is pretty terrible, because a much clearer tutorial could probably be coded up in a work day, but they didn't do that.  Even though paradox is a massive company with many successful titles in this exact genre - so, it's not like they've never done this sort of game before, or had to write tutorials for these sort of games before.  It also sets the scenery poorly - like you have to infer that, for the sake of the tutorial, you're playing as germany.  Just because a grand strategy is basically a digital board game, doesn't mean that you don't have to scrap all attempts at presentation.  You don't lose out on the game for presenting it a little better.  I'm not asking for lens flares and all the faggy pizzaz that goes on in modern games, purely meant to catch the eye and be distracting as♥♥♥♥♥♥  I'm not asking for that.  I'm just asking for proper presentation that facillitates quick learning.  The tutorial doesn't even highlight the parts of the screen you're supposed to be reading very well, but that's a much more minor point.Here's an example of wording - 'You can build divisions in the production menu.  Divisions are made up of brigades.  You only get 4 (brigades?  divisions?), but our troops are so good that you only need 4 (brigades?  divisions?)'.  It's that sort of 'short hand' tone that can make everything else unclear.  If you don't know whether ol' Adolf is talking about divisions or brigades, then it's hard to figure out what the actual rules are.  In order to play a game, you need to know the rules - in order to get good at a game, you need to know how to play within the limits, so that you can tweak your style and discover an optimal level.  A game can have a steeper 'learning curve' effectively by obscuring the player's ability to percieve what is optimal - but there should be a point, I feel, at which the player can see everything that needs to be done to reach an optimal level (maybe after 100 hours of playing the game or so).  I think most players like organization - a game can only be chaotic if the means of playing it is simple.  It's a replayable game when the player can continue to have fun, riding the point of optimization (insert sexual metaphor here).  It's a confusing game, however, when the point of optimization is too obscure, or the goal posts keep shifting.  Unless the point of optimization is growing accustomed to the shifting goal posts, but it shouldn't take more than 100 hours to be able to see where that point lies.  It can take much longer than 100 hours to reach that level, but if the player can see how close they're getting there, they can still be hooked by the game.  Does this make sense?  It's my opinion that some devs have figured this out, and others haven't.------Second issue thus far:- The game crashes when I alt-tab out and try to go back into the game.  I don't understand what causes any game to do this.  Is it the display coding?  I've played several games that don't experience this problem (maybe because they're all capable of windowed mode), but there's plenty of others that can't handle alt-tabbing.  It's one of many software conundrums.  --------Other than that, I haven't had much problem, so I'll recommend the game because grandtards like northern lion love it, so y'know.  Who'm I to judge?  I might get into the game, but it'll probably take another 10 hours re-looking at the tutorials and ♥♥♥♥ing up in the regular game.

												This is a re-write of my previous review of Hearts of iron 3. My last review of this game was very high, but time goes by and things tend to change, dramaticly sometimes. for some reason this game has not aged well, This game was in it's time a masterpiece with micro management down to squad level, with the operating systems of today, the developers have not been updating it prooperly. it constantly crashes to desktop, and nothing is being done about it. the game menu is very sloppy made (or updated) like white text on white background, so that you can not see what it reads on the buttons, you also can not chose wich mod to start because of this. because you cannot see what it says, this is poorly updated or just sloppy,I am sure that would be a small task for the developer to just change to black text, well Im guessing that, I have about zero knowledge about programing. but overall, it seems the game is not updated to newer operating systems, well, I run Windows seven and Win8 has been out for years atm. Hearts of iron 3 do not use a hexagon grid, for a game of this size I really wish it would have, the gameplay would have been so much better, with not using a grid, the result is that enemy forces can just slip behind your lines just like that, and there is no real way to block them. it is really a mess. this is something paradox uses in most all their games. however, HOI3 have been a very good game and it still is if you are able to run it, it is a shame to see that  such a great game as this go waisted, the crashes are really annoying because you put in a lot of time in it, you build your country improves production, all this takes hours and then suddenly it crashes and all is lost so you have to start over again, sure you could save often but still you can not save every minute because this is a real time strategy game, so it is easy to forget your self in the midle of strategic planing, if it where turnbased it would not have been such a problem, with all that said, I can not recommend this game at the current date because of these problems, I assume there is not many guys out there running XP today, so they should fix this, but if you DO run Windows XP, poor guy, then go ahead and buy it right off the bat, it will probably work just fine for you,but I can not guarantie it because as I wrote earlyer, I run Win7. keep in mind that at his time there are allmost only good reviews of this game on Steam, so if you manage to find this review, like a needle in the sand, be rest assured that the good reviews are presumably old and from the time when the game worked, therefore you should possibly give this review more weight. the date of writing this review is 2014-09-21, if there would be a patch fixing this in the future, I will rewrite this review. but until then, the game is totally unplayable and I can not give it more than 1/10 because of that, and I recommend that you do not buy this game.

												You're holding out against the Allies who are constantly amassing on your western front, and on your eastern front, where most of your forces are, your forces are pushing through the comintern forces who are constantly running out of supplies due to your strategic bombing runs, broken from the nightly bombings, and slaughtered through your superior tactics, combat experience, generals, and timing.This game is extremely complex, many decisions ranging from managing your country's economy, historical events such as the olympics and the spanish civil war, deciding where you should place more factories to fuel your war machine, to researching technology such as radios and even the nuclear bomb. The combat is very rewarding and fun, favoring those players who take their time to plan and pay close attention to details such as the weather, wind, climate, and landscape. YOU choose how you want to play. You can play as Germany and decide to play defensively on the western front, while you focus on the eastern front, crushing the russian forces, or play as Mexico and join the Axis, destroying weakening the U.S economy and splitting up their forces so Italy and Germany can more easily take over all of Europe. You can play as ANY country such as Japan, Swizterland, Turkey, Ethiopia, Mongolia, Communist China, Nationalist China, etc.TL;DR: Best strategy game ever.

												Fantastic game. One of my all time favourites. Grand Strategy isn't for everyone but HOI3 is a great place to start, especially if you love World War Two history, deep and complex game play and building the ultimate war machine. Just don't be surprised if you have to spend a little more time learning the ropes then in most games. Graphically this 5 year old title holds up pretty well, largely due to a fairly simplistic yet functional graphical style. As for the audio, the sound effects are just 'ok' but the sound track is very well done. The game itself is largely bug free although the AI is at best competent. Thankfully there is still an active modding community that provides everything from graphical to AI to complete overhaul changes. Definitely consider this title if you're looking to try something new and are passionate about history and strategy.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Hearts of Iron III, simply put, is a spectacularly good grand strategy game. Though players will initially find it daunting due to the number of mechanics in play at once (your first war will most certainly be confusing), if you take the time to learn the gameplay mechanics, either by playing or searching online, you'll eventually get to grips with it - it took me no longer than about 5-10 hours to understand most of the important game mechanics, though I still occasionally find myself learning something new. That said, I have some friends who haven't been able to understand the gameplay (which turned multiplayer into a bit of a hand-holding scenario), so it won't be for everyone. Once you've gotten into the real meat-and-bones of the gameplay, Hearts of Iron III has a lot to offer. The number of nations available for the player to choose is simply amazing - you can choose anybody from the mighty USSR down to Luxembourg or Costa Rica, and this really allows the gameplay to evolve with every new game. This, along with the ability to completely alter the history of the world in the 1930s and 1940s, is what really makes the game shine. Freedom is granted to the player to make an aggressive superpower out of Sweden, or to launch an invasion of the U.S.A as Nazi Germany. The scope of the game is immense, and the detail on the campaign map is brilliant. The combat, once you've got the hang of it, is fun, and the wars you will find yourself in can take anywhere from a minute to several days of gameplay to bring to a conclusion. The AI is occasionally partial to moments of pants-on-head stupidity though, which sometimes let the game down a bit. Multiplayer, although I haven't played much of it admittedly, was good for the most part. Gameplay is, of course, identical to the campaign, but the new elements that a human player, as opposed to an AI, bring to the game make it downright entertaining. Player politics in the multiplayer can be treacherous (indeed, a good comparison for the player politics in the multiplayer would be to Risk, or Civ 5), but it also allows for some interesting co-operation between historical rivals (the USSR and Nazi Germany in one of my games, for instance - though admittedly this came with a great deal of backstabbing on my behalf!). Overall, it's a wonderfully well presented Grand strategy game. The world is your sandbox, and history is ripe for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation. If you have the time to spare to get to grasps with the gameplay, I'd fully recommend it. It is, however, a real time sink, so if you don't have that much free time, it may not be for you.
