												I have lost count the amount of my life I have lost playing this game because its that good :-)Although I wouldn't give it 10/10 because there are some major flaws that give this 10/10 but I would say 8/10 would be a fairer assesment.  The game has become more complex but in some ways better for it, the creation of armies has now come more structured so you can spread your specialisation abit more. For instance an army could have a corp dedicated to attack fortifications via their generals or brigades. Its lost some of its military accuracy and some of the pictures do not represent the item you can build, for instance a Tiger tank shows a British heavy instead.However I will advise on what I think is wrong and why it looses 2 points.1: Alliance features.Wheather you decide to be the Allied powers or the Axis powers, they never seem to work together except use the ability to use friendly territory. A negative review below puts it correctlly, in this game they added the ability to create battleplans or use historical ones, but they do not work, the allies required do not follow though with the plan and do not offer units. An example of this would be Operation Torch and Husky. I played as the US yet the Brits did not help out in either operation. That being said if I was to counter argue this, one could say that because this game is unique that history never really plays out as it does historically, its possible that the Brits had all their transport ships sunk and are struggling to build more, also the fact that  they lost Africa doesn't help either. But that in its own way is a vilification that the game AI lacks the ability to think strategically and historically.2: The airforceI encountered this same problem in HoI2, were you could have top airforce training for your fighters and interceptors, and even good research, yet go up against anything, intercept bombers or even go fighter hunting, it seems to struggle to work correctly and always leaves me requiring to heal my fighters more often then anything else. Air attacks against ground forces is either hit or miss, either they do what there supposed to do or do nothing at all. I find the only really effective options is strategic bombing, which actually do damage to cities and cause some really nasty problems. But there is a negative there also, if you were to focus historically on WW2, Germany and Japan where on their knees near 1944 and 45 due to the effectiveness of stragegic bombing. New equipment could not be built quick enough and resources became low as factories became ineffective due to either lack of resources or their own destruction. Yet in HoI3 a country can overcome a bout of bombing very quickly and shake it off like a light bang on the head. This makes things a little boring and in the end you focus your efforts elsewhere.Inspite these issues I love this game and always revert back to it when I am bored of other games which is becoming often. There is so much to do in this game that offers new challenges, and more uncertain outcomes. As HoI4 in well into its development I will eventually get that, hopefully it will improve the areas I have gripped about, but we will see.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Hearts of Iron III is a massive WWII Real-Time simulation. Play as the Germans and storm through Europe or as America building a massive army to prepare for the unavoidable war. The game itself has a bit of a learning curve as each unit has multiple stats you must consider, mixed combination make it even more complicated, but the core come down to the strategy involved in your invasions and pre-planning. There are many ways to play the game, I'm partial to using Germany to take over Italy just because they are only good for bugging France some. 												Having finally gotten over the steep learning curve (made a lot faster by watching Michael Broschek's tutorials), I can say this game is a lot easier than it looks at first glance. Similar to Dwarf Fortress, when I first started playing, it looked to be an impermeable mess of menus and overcomplicated gibberish, but once you finally dove in (perhaps after watching a let's play or the tutorials as I mentioned above), everything slowly pieces itself together. The first game you play, you can expect to make a TON of mistakes, but after your first playthrough, everything should start becoming more natural to you, and you'll improve with every subsequent playthrough (learning where to focus first, what your strategy should be, how to actually use the AI for handling theatres, and so on).For anyone who is looking for a very in-depth grand strategy experience, I'd say look no further than Hearts of Iron 3 (although I do suggest you try out Paraodox's easier grand strategy games like Europa Universalis IV and Crusader Kings 2 to acclimate yourself to the engine). Every country in the world that exists during this time period is playable (although good luck as El Salvador...), and you aren't limited to just the major powers. However, if you do pick up Hearts of Iron 3, I highly suggest getting all of the expansions with it, as well as using large address aware (LAA) on the game's .exe (the lack of LAA practically broke the game on my system).

The learning curve is very large but it worth leaning in order to gain hundreds of hours of enjoyment from this title. 												924 hours. That is my total playtime of this game on steam, not counting my playtime via the gamersgate version which I also now own. I think that speaks for itself, but to give a brief summary of my thoughts, well, I can only say this: This is a game that will not appeal to many people. It takes a lot of practice, patience, and a love for long term planning and geopolitical strategy over combat and fast paced action. It also takes a love for history, the detail and the intrigues, and lastly, a large amount of, well, 'geekness'. For those of you who are history buffs, or who want to play a genuinely different type of strategy, pick this up, now. It is worth noting however that Hearts of Iron 2, and in particular Darkest Hour: A hearts of iron game, are in the political and detail senses generally superior games, but if you like any one of these games, you will like all of them for what they are, and that is a solid experience produced by an equally solid and player-focused developer.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Hearts of Iron III, simply put, is a spectacularly good grand strategy game. Though players will initially find it daunting due to the number of mechanics in play at once (your first war will most certainly be confusing), if you take the time to learn the gameplay mechanics, either by playing or searching online, you'll eventually get to grips with it - it took me no longer than about 5-10 hours to understand most of the important game mechanics, though I still occasionally find myself learning something new. That said, I have some friends who haven't been able to understand the gameplay (which turned multiplayer into a bit of a hand-holding scenario), so it won't be for everyone. Once you've gotten into the real meat-and-bones of the gameplay, Hearts of Iron III has a lot to offer. The number of nations available for the player to choose is simply amazing - you can choose anybody from the mighty USSR down to Luxembourg or Costa Rica, and this really allows the gameplay to evolve with every new game. This, along with the ability to completely alter the history of the world in the 1930s and 1940s, is what really makes the game shine. Freedom is granted to the player to make an aggressive superpower out of Sweden, or to launch an invasion of the U.S.A as Nazi Germany. The scope of the game is immense, and the detail on the campaign map is brilliant. The combat, once you've got the hang of it, is fun, and the wars you will find yourself in can take anywhere from a minute to several days of gameplay to bring to a conclusion. The AI is occasionally partial to moments of pants-on-head stupidity though, which sometimes let the game down a bit. Multiplayer, although I haven't played much of it admittedly, was good for the most part. Gameplay is, of course, identical to the campaign, but the new elements that a human player, as opposed to an AI, bring to the game make it downright entertaining. Player politics in the multiplayer can be treacherous (indeed, a good comparison for the player politics in the multiplayer would be to Risk, or Civ 5), but it also allows for some interesting co-operation between historical rivals (the USSR and Nazi Germany in one of my games, for instance - though admittedly this came with a great deal of backstabbing on my behalf!). Overall, it's a wonderfully well presented Grand strategy game. The world is your sandbox, and history is ripe for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation. If you have the time to spare to get to grasps with the gameplay, I'd fully recommend it. It is, however, a real time sink, so if you don't have that much free time, it may not be for you.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												This is still arguably the best strategic WW2 sim available, despite its flaws. The one chief complaint by many seems to be the inherent level of micromanagement contained within this game and its predecessors, but if you're someone that dislikes micromanagement, then why are you even looking at this game in the first place?This is a game for someone that loves history, loves hardcore simulations, and loves to manage things down to the lowest possible level. Sure, you certainly can automate some game functions to a degree. But HOI3 gives you the power to take control directly, and the possibilities are endless because of it. And with the latest 'Their Finest Hour' expansion, your inner field marshal will shake with joy at the addition of battle plan editing, which allows you do do your own operational-level chief of staff work and create battle plans complete with movement arrows and other annotations, just like something out of Manstein's 'Lost Battles,' or Patton's memoirs. So the bottom line is that if you love love WW2 history, historical simulations, and don't have a short attention span, then this game is most certainly for you!

Posted: November 26, 2015
												(Play time is considerably higher than displayed on steam. Game can be played without running steam.)I can't recommend HOI 3. Being a fan of the predecessor, with undreds of hours of playtime, I've never felt at home with the third installment.I looked forward to see the concept enhanced and refined, receiving a sandbox game giving me even more options to play out all the crazy "what if" scenarios.Instead I got a pretty clunky piece of software which ran at a considerably lower speed without making any real use of the 3D graphics engine, apart from introducing tons of micro DLCs for unit types.But what annoyed me most, is the fact that the game is way less transparent than the predecessor, offering even less freedom of choice. It mediates the player: Instead of giving him more control, it forces him to follow the pace of the predestined alliances if he wishes to actually take part in the game. While this can be circumvened with lots of ingame time, th fact that you are resigned to watch the computer play persists.Moving your armies, executing certain troop movements like a grand encirclment is not what you are supposed to do. You just watch time tick away, while the computer is moving the troops. HOI 3 was a huge disappointment for me. I really tried to get in touch with it, but even after several playthrough as minor and major powers I didn't feel involved the way I did with HOI2.Funny enough I discovered "Arsenal of Democracy", a modification to enhance and refine HOI2, months later. And it was exactly what I hoped HOI3 would offer me. All it lacks is the larger amount of provinces which are provided by HOI3. Playing Arsenal of Democracy, I don't see a reason to return to HOI3.So, no recommendation. Sorry, Paradox. Hope you'll do better with HOI4.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Having finally gotten over the steep learning curve (made a lot faster by watching Michael Broschek's tutorials), I can say this game is a lot easier than it looks at first glance. Similar to Dwarf Fortress, when I first started playing, it looked to be an impermeable mess of menus and overcomplicated gibberish, but once you finally dove in (perhaps after watching a let's play or the tutorials as I mentioned above), everything slowly pieces itself together. The first game you play, you can expect to make a TON of mistakes, but after your first playthrough, everything should start becoming more natural to you, and you'll improve with every subsequent playthrough (learning where to focus first, what your strategy should be, how to actually use the AI for handling theatres, and so on).For anyone who is looking for a very in-depth grand strategy experience, I'd say look no further than Hearts of Iron 3 (although I do suggest you try out Paraodox's easier grand strategy games like Europa Universalis IV and Crusader Kings 2 to acclimate yourself to the engine). Every country in the world that exists during this time period is playable (although good luck as El Salvador...), and you aren't limited to just the major powers. However, if you do pick up Hearts of Iron 3, I highly suggest getting all of the expansions with it, as well as using large address aware (LAA) on the game's .exe (the lack of LAA practically broke the game on my system).

												Not that I don't like the control I get over an economy, industry, diplomacy, military of a WW2 nation, but it's not for me. For one, you don't really "manage" intelligence and politics, you just set a couple bars and hope it works out. For another, not everything is explained...at all. Watch Youtube videos to better understand some of the mechanics.Personally, if you want to just jump in and get experience, play America to practice controlling an economy and industry, then go Italy for some military experience. Diplomacy matters more to Italy than America, but mostly it's just historical events. DO NOT GO AS GERMANY IF YOU ARE CLUELESS! THE WAR STARTS, AND LARGELY FOR THE FIRST 2 YEARS, RUNS ON THEIR SCHEDULE! YOU WILL BE OVERWHELMED BY HOW MUCH STUFF HAPPENS AT ONCE!Also, managing armies isn't always straightforward. Note: if you're army has no supplies, it can move, but it cannot attack an enemy army (can still occupy territory I believe). You will take longer to move over rivers and in mountains without engineers (train lots). Finally, you cannot post any troops in terrritories with less than 2 infrastructure. Seriously, they are foot pounders...WHY DO THEY HAVE TO HAVE A ROAD SYSTEM!?Also also, while commanders give bonuses, it's not an easy system to understand. FYI: you set the stars, or "seniority" of commanders (just dictates how high a command they CAN take). Higher level: higher command since it'll take awhile to level up...unless they have an ability that's really handy to a particular army right now. Lower levels: tend to be front-line leaders, but not all abilities are useful (ie. supplies reduction is likely useful in Theatre (highest) command, since the most troops will be effected (even if the general is a lower skill level)Overall, while the sheer ability to command all major aspects of a WW2 nation is nice, not all commands are created equal, not all features and mechanics are explained in useful detail, and at times there is simply too much micro-management for someone like me to enjoy. Good effort, but improvement is definately possible and I'd argue nessecarry for this series.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Absolutely love this game and can easily lose a weekend to playing it. As a WWII history buff, I appreciate the amount of detail and work that has gone into this game! I particularly enjoy the randomness of starting off with one of the preset scenarios (1936, 1939, etc) as a Major actor in the war and watching it evolve differently than recorded history with just a few policy or diplomacy changes. For example, playing as the U.S. starting in 1936, I placed a large focus on my naval and ground power and gave mere lip service to production and development of my air assets. Though I was able to win the battle in the Pacific against Japan by 1944 forcing surrender without using Nukes, and able to neutralize Italy in marching from Sicily to Switzerland, I was mired in the battle for Fortress Europe as I learned quickly that not having adequate air power against the German Luftwaffe in France as well as the Low Countries was not a great strategy. My bombers were pummeled every time they lifted off, air support that I sent as escorts were being swatted out of the sky like flies and the Luftwaffe bombers made me pay for every square I took in battle. My only wish was that there were a proper way to co-ordinate with the AI/Allies to achieve objectives to more closely simulate real operations (Dragoon, Torch, Overlord, etc.) as the one that is currently in place is pretty ineffectual. Aside from that, I will continue playing this until the next iteration hits the market.Absolutely recommended!

												Hearts Of Iron is a great game with good game mechanics that are hard to understand at some points in the game but become real easy once understanding it. One key feature you need to know is the chain of command that is how you get supplies to your units without wasting a lot of them. The chain of command works like this you make a division then click on it press the 3x's that will make a corps then click the corps and click the 4x's that makes an army then click the amry and press the 5x's this will make and army group. now you thinks its over right well no now click the amry group and press the button with a green arrow and 3 bars. this will allow you to connect this to a theatre. connect it and their your done, but remember the magic number is 5. 5 divsion under 1 corps. 5 corps under one army. 5 armies under 1 army group and 5 army groups under 1 theater. thats the chain of command.

												I highly recommend this game, especially for those who enjoy studying history and enjoy alternate history scenarios. However, this game is all about micromanaging and is not for those who wish to jump in and play like in Call of Duty or other examples. The learning curve is very large but it worth leaning in order to gain hundreds of hours of enjoyment from this title. I would recommend starting off from a less in depth Grand Strategy game if you are not experienced, something like Crusader Kings 2 or Europa Universalis IV, and then moving on to this game. but once you know how it works inside and out, you are bound for some very fun times. Want to see what would happen if France had stopped the Germans, if Japan had invaded the west coast of the United States, if Russia had not been able to push back Germany, or even if the United States had never joined the Allies? Then you will love this game and enjoy it for years ahead.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Able to play any country from 1936-1948, hour by hour with adjustable speeds even in multiplayer, though only major powers and some regionals are worth playing.  Game really rewards thinking ahead, as in months and years (game time) ahead.  Multiplayer is recommended, AI is easy to beat, though it'll still put up a good enough fight for you to enjoy singleplayer.  All 3 expansions are REQUIRED, they add and fix so many things, the game is not worth playing without them.  (Expansions are Semper Fi, For the Motherland, and Their Finest Hour, do NOT bother with any other DLC, except the music packs if you want those.)This is a war game, don't expect any diplomatic, cultural, scientific, or economic victories.  The only thing that matters at the end of the day is whose troops are in the capitols of their enemies.Air operations are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to manage.Naval operations are simple but get the job done.Ground operations are where this game ♥♥♥♥ing shines.The Order Of Battle can be a little annoying to set up.Diplomacy is very simple, as is Intelligence and Internal Politics, generally allowing you to set and forget.Research and Production are where you have the most freedom to do as you wish with your country.Your basic air units are Air Wings, which you group up into 2s, 3s, or 4s, and have them perform whatever role they're designed to, Interceptors will generally be flying air superiority or interception, Close Air Support will generally be bombing enemy ground units, etc.Ships larger than a destroyer are produced individually and grouped together to form task forces which perform whatever mission they can from the ships assigned.  Carriers can be sent to bomb enemy ports or fleets, Battleships are generally used to form the fighting line of your fleets, engaging other battleships, bombarding, etc.  Destroyers are represented by Destroyer Flotillas, each Destroyer Flotilla in game is supposed to represent about 3 Destroyers, they are used to screen your larger ships.Your basic ground unit is the Division, which is made up of individual brigades of your choice, anything from your standard Infantry brigade to Artillery brigades or Heavy Armour brigades, there are a lot of choices.  The brigades all add certain bonuses and maluses to the division as a whole and this determines how effective it is in combat in the various terrains against other divisions.  There is a lot that goes into what makes a good division, terrain, cost (in industrial capacity, supplies, and manpower), tech level, your enemies, and more.  Countries like the USA can afford to go heavy on support units and armour because of their abundance of everything, while other countries like Japan may find itself not being able to make a lot of support or armour because of their shortages of everything, nor would they normally want to make a lot of armour because of all the low infrastructure mountains and jungles they'll usually find themselves fighting in (not the best tank country).  You'll find yourself fielding a number of different types of divisions for all the situations you'll be dealing with.Most games against the AI will play out historically until 1941 or 42, it will not deviate from the script, though sometimes it can make a mistake against the other AI and get bogged down taking longer to do what it historically did.  After 1942 it's all up in the air depending on how you and the various AI are doing.  Against other players, this game offers a lot of different routes to alternate history scenarios.Definitely worth picking up on a sale if you're into WW2 games or grand strategy games in general.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Oh man, where to begin?Ever felt like video-games are too shallow and bring nothing new to our zeitgeist? Ever wished you could go back in time and relive the tension and world-defining moments of World War 2? Ever thought you could do a better job than the Führer or Il Duce? Were you one of those insufferable kids that would take Risk as serious as a real world conflict? Well, you can stop reading right here and get this game already.In case you need reassurance, here's a proper review of the game just for you: Hearts of Iron 3 is the august title of what's called grand strategy games. In these, you control large, complex portions of a nation state's resources to wage war, conquer, thrive and, well, win. Hearts of Iron 3 is set in the specific timeframe of the Second World War: You'll be able to choose where and how you start, in any year ranging from 1936 to well into the end of the war. It is possible to play the game until the mid 50s, depending on how things play out. You can play as any country that existed in the world during the thirties and forties, literally any. A good deal of those countries will have events and decisions designed specificaly for them. Once you choose your country, its time to dive into the game: Politics, diplomacy, industrial production, army, naval and air force management, intelligence, espionage, economy and everything else you can fathom will be under your control. Make sure the right political party is ruling your country, choose the best government approaches, decide whats going to be build where, move your divisions to key locations and make sure those are well commanded and well supplied, make allies and enemies and rewrite some ♥♥♥♥ing history.I ain't gonna lie: It's difficult. First few hours playing are spent in tutorials and learning by trial and mistake. There so much to do and so many things to decide that you are bound to ♥♥♥♥ something up, and that's probably going to send your dreams of winning World War 2 crashing down to the ground. But nevermind that, because Hearts of Iron 3 is the kind of game where even losing can be fun. I remember fondly my many last stands against impossible odds, in fact those seem to stick in my memory more than any victory.Try playing as Poland instead of Germany and see how long you can last against the  blitzkrieg	. Play as Turkey and hold on to your♥♥♥♥♥♥while joining the Axis and declaring war on the USSR. Maybe pick China and show those japanese filth it won't be that easy♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Nanking this time around. First time I played the game after learning the basics, I joined the Axis as Brazil and nuked London to open the way for Operation Sea Lion. Good times, man. Good times.Don't be afraid of tackling the learning curve of this game. It'll be worth.Gameplay - 10/10Soundtrack - 9/10Graphics - 5/10Content - 9/10Challenge Level - 9/10Replayability - 10/10
